CHEM 311.course_description: SP. Chemistry and chemical techniques play a pivotal role in the disciplines of forensic science and toxicology. In this course, students will learn how to apply presumptive and confirmatory tests for specific applications in forensic science. Students will then explore the chemistry of poisons at the trace element and molecular level, and the chemical and biochemical mechanisms of toxicity.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 311L.course_description: SP. In this lab, students will learn to differentiate between presumptive and confirmatory forensic tests. Students will engage in hands-on activities using GC-MS, FTIR, and X-ray fluorescence to analyze toxic substances and fibers. Advanced instrumental approaches and simulations will also be used to study poison-receptor binding and binding effects.   Corequisite(s):

CHEM 341.course_description: SP. How do you create increasingly large and complex molecules? Central to answering this question is the ability to control a reaction’s mechanism, product distribution, or material properties. This course will focus on the synthesis of complicated molecules. Synthesis encompasses a variety of strategies, such as total synthesis, biosynthesis, and polymeric synthesis. Special attention will be paid to asymmetric control of traditional organic reactions, particularly using catalytic methods, as well as the growing application of catalysis and synthetic methods for the generation of high-performance polymers.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 341L.course_description: SP. In this lab, students will complete sequential, multi-step syntheses based on procedures found in the literature. All compounds prepared will be characterized using spectroscopic methods and other instrumental techniques. Organometallic catalysts will be made and evaluated for their application to complex connections and chiral induction. Special attention will be paid to the synthesis and use of polymers in complex transformations.   Corequisite(s):

CHEM 353.course_description: FA. An understanding of the fundamentals of quantum mechanics is valuable for every chemistry and biochemistry student. Exploring foundational questions, this course emphasizes solving the Schrödinger equation to understand the ultimate sources of microscopic modes of motion, including translation, vibration, rotation, as well as electronic transitions. Students will cultivate an understanding of quantum chemistry, equipping them to unravel the intricacies of chemical bonding and molecular spectroscopy. This course opens the door to the mysteries of quantum phenomena and provides a platform for continued studies in chemistry, physics, or related fields.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 353L.course_description: FA. This lab offers a practical and hands-on approach to exploring experimental and computational applications of quantum chemistry, including molecular spectroscopy, electronic structure calculations, and the utilization of lasers in various experiments. Through these hands-on activities, students will gain experience in applying quantum chemical principles to real-world scenarios, preparing them for future studies and careers in the chemical and physical sciences.   Corequisite(s):

CHEM 371.course_name: Chemistry and Sustainability: Life Cycle of an Electric Car
CHEM 371.course_description: FA. Industrial chemistry shapes our lives and impacts the environment in many substantial ways. Along with the amazing advances that result from materials technology, many processes also negatively impact the environment. This course will address selected topics from areas of chemistry that impact our climate, our habitat, and human health. Emphasis will be on the chemistry and thermodynamics of these processes with a focus not only on the production but also on the deconstruction to assess the overall sustainability of a marquee example: the electric car.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 371L.course_description: FA. In this lab, students will conduct experiments related to battery chemistry and electrochemical processes. Students will also explore aspects of sustainability, including atmospheric impacts, minimizing mining and maximizing recycling, to understand the environmental impact of technologies and how they may be made more sustainable.   Corequisite(s):

CHEM 372.course_description: FA. This course will introduce students to nanomaterials with a special focus on the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles. Various applications of nanoparticles from cosmetics to targeted drug delivery in medicine to their potential toxicity will be introduced. A particular focus will be placed on understanding instrumental methods used to characterize the physical and chemical properties of nanoparticles with a special emphasis on using a UV-Vis spectrophotometer.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 372L.course_description: FA. In this lab, students will perform hands-on experiments with the synthesis and characterization of nanoparticles. Analysis of the nanoparticles will be accomplished with various approaches, starting with UV-Vis spectroscopy. Students will explore the various components of a single-beam and dual-beam UV spectrometer and monitor the catalytic activity of nanoparticles by time-resolved UV-vis spectroscopy. Students will use additional instrumental techniques (FTIR, MP-AES, XRF) and visualization techniques (Atomic Force Microscopy, Image Analysis) to further characterize nanoparticles.   Corequisite(s):

CHEM 373.course_description: FA. The d-orbitals dominate the chemistry of the transition metals. Though limited in abundance, these elements with their special electronic structure can be found all over the planet and used in nature and by humans to do everything from catalyzing functional reactions to forming exquisite structures. Students in this course will go deeper into various aspects of metal chemistry. Areas for exploration are supramolecular chemistry, coordination chemistry, organometallic chemistry, materials science, and metals in biological systems and processes.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 373L.course_description: FA. In this lab, students will study systems that include metal ions using (bio)synthetic, spectroscopic, and computational methods. These experiments will prepare students to make and characterize the wide variety of molecules and materials that include transition metals.   Corequisite(s):

CHEM 295.course_description: FA, SP. A seminar devoted to an exploration of topics in current chemical research in both academic and industrial laboratories. To be taken a minimum of twice by chemistry and biochemistry BA students and three times by those pursuing a BS or ACS-Certified degree. Junior and senior chemistry majors are encouraged to attend.

CHEM 390.course_description: FA, SP. Directed readings or projects. Admission by permission of the chair and instructor under whom the work will be done. To be enrolled in this course, the student must submit a completed research agreement form to the office of academic services and the department office.

CHEM 394.course_description: FA, SP. Research on a project selected in consultation with a faculty member at Calvin University during the academic year. 45 hours per credit if taken for credit, or 45 hours per semester hour toward an ACS or honors chemistry degree if taken for zero credit. This course may be taken more than once. The student will be required to write a report and complete all tasks specified by the supervisor. To be enrolled in this course, the student must submit a completed research agreement form to the office of academic services and the department office.

CHEM 395.course_description: FA, SP. A research presentation is given in

CHEM 396.course_description: FA, SP. Students will complete a formal written report consistent with the requirements of their chemistry subdiscipline. The report will be written based on data collected during a research project or as a part of a 300-level chemistry lab. As part of the ACS degree, the report will be reviewed by a department committee of two additional chemistry faculty alongside the supervising faculty.  Prerequisite(s): acquisition of scientific data that can be the basis for a formal lab report through

CHEM 397.course_description: SU. This course indicates the completion of supervised research (~400 hours) during the summer related to chemistry or biochemistry. A student who has been accepted into a summer research program, either at Calvin or elsewhere, should register for this course during the summer in which they are completing the research. The student will be required to write a report and complete all tasks specified by their supervisor. This course may be completed more than once.

CHEM 399.course_description: A single test covering all subdisciplines that is administered to all students graduating with a chemistry or biochemistry major.  Prerequisite(s): successful completion of all other courses required for a chemistry or biochemistry major.

CHEM 398.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Off-campus chemistry internships can be arranged for qualified students. Students work at least 60 hours per credit, under the supervision of an off-campus employer-supervisor and an internship coordinator. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship can be counted toward graduation requirements. Interns meet with their faculty coordinator regularly and submit a final written report summarizing their internship experience. The off-campus supervisor sends in an evaluation report on the work of the intern. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry and have received approval from the Department Chair. Applications can be initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department. To be enrolled in this course, the student must submit a completed and signed research agreement form to the office of academic services.

CHIN 101.course_description: FA. An introduction to Chinese language and culture, stressing both spoken and written Chinese. After one semester, students will be able to carry on simple conversations in (Mandarin) Chinese, read dialogues written in Chinese, and understand some fundamentals of Chinese social values and ways of thinking. Approximately 300 Chinese characters will be introduced.

CLAS 211.course_description: FA, SP, alternate years. This is a study of the major works of Greek and Roman literature from Homer to Augustine. The course devotes attention to the origins and development of Greek epic, lyric, drama, and historiography, and to their transformation in the literature of Rome and the church fathers. Artistic and archaeological evidence supplements the study of the texts.     Not offered in 2024-25.

CLAS 231.course_description: FA, SP, alternate years. This is a study of the major themes in classical mythology via the literature and art of Greece and Rome. The course includes a study of major literary sources in translation and major art works of both cultures, with special attention to various interpretations of the myths and the works of art they have influenced in the development of Western culture.

COMM 101.course_description: FA, SP. What is one of the top skills all employers look for in future employees? Effective oral communication. Being able to speak well in public also will help you in other courses, student and community groups, and in your church. In this course you will learn the fundamental skills of oral rhetoric—how to create a message strategically adapted for a specific audience (for this semester, your fellow students in this class) and situation. You will also learn how to effectively deliver your speeches and how to be an engaged, thoughtful listener.

COMM 141.course_description: SP. In this course, we will learn both how to “read” and create images that persuade others. We will study the strengths and weaknesses of both images and words; using that knowledge, we can better analyze and create messages that use both visual and written rhetoric. We also will examine the ethical responsibility of both viewers and creators of images so that we are truthful, respectful, and fair in our practices. Building on this knowledge, we will finish the course with students creating intentional, ethical persuasive messages adapted to a well-defined target audience.

COMM 145.course_description: FA, SP. A study of film and other moving image media as art forms and cultural phenomena, including dramatic, visual, and sonic elements, theme and focus, acting, and directorial style. Topics covered include the materials and methods of media production, the major styles and genres of moving image media, and the relationship of film and television to American and world culture. Course work includes a mandatory weekly screening (lab) and readings in the history, theory, and criticism of film and television.   Corequisite(s):

COMM 145L.course_name: Introduction to Film and Media Lab
COMM 145L.course_description: FA, SP. Corequisite lab course for

COMM 180.course_description: FA, SP. An introduction to the principles and practice of communicating a message to an audience through digital images (still pictures, moving pictures, and graphics) and digital sound (voice, music, ambient sound, and sound effects). Students will learn the fundamental techniques of preproduction planning, camera use, lighting, sound, and editing in order to communicate their ideas effectively, artistically, and ethically. Students also will learn to communicate their messages through digital channels, especially the Internet. The course will enable students interested in social media, public relations, advertising, journalism, corporate training, sales, e-learning, publishing, worship, and the arts to realize ideas through sound and image. Students intending to take advanced Media Production courses must take

COMM 190.course_description: FA, SP. An introductory course in film-style production. Instruction includes sound and image capture, editing, pre-production planning, and lighting. Students will produce a series of exercises and a short film. Equipment is provided. This course is a prerequisite for 200- and 300-level film and media production courses.

COMM 200.course_description: SP. Through careful study and practice of the principles of effective, ethical, and eloquent oral rhetoric, students will become excellent communicators and will appreciate excellent oral communication. This course teaches students the composition and presentation of various types of speeches, building on the student learning and experiences of

COMM 201.course_description: FA. This course offers students an advanced understanding of new media technologies, especially the ways in which new media have influenced human communication practices.  Students will investigate online communities, virtual environments, new media technologies, digital communication strategies, and a variety of contemporary issues in the computerization of communication in work, home, church and public discourse. Students will explore in-depth social media and video games and will learn how to create effective, ethical social media content strategies.

COMM 222.course_description: FA, SP. Students learn basic media production skills by contributing to the creation of a film, radio, and/or television production in the context of an advanced student project, a client project, or under the supervision of a staff and/or faculty advisor. Students may participate more than one semester, but no more than four semester hours may be applied toward major or graduation requirements.  Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.

COMM 248.course_description: FA, SP. An introduction to the content, styles, structure, and format of screenplays. The course emphasizes the role of the screenplay as text in screen storytelling, the styles of writing used, and the technical requirements for screenplays used to focus the work of directors, actors, camera, and sound technicians, editors and mixers in creating a media product.  Prerequisite(s):

COMM 249.course_description: FA, SP. This course introduces basic audio principles for filmmaking and podcasting, including interview and field recording techniques, and basic mixing, editing, and effects. This course is a prerequisite for

COMM 250.course_description: An introduction to the theory and practice of studio-based video production. Various program formats are discussed and evaluated in light of particular communication principles and needs. Students gain experience with stationary video cameras, recorders, switchers, and related technologies. Performance for the camera, studio lighting, audio recording, and mixing principles are analyzed and demonstrated.  Prerequisite(s):

COMM 251.course_description: SP. This course introduces students to multitrack studio recording and front-of-house mixing techniques, including the use of advanced consoles and microphone setups.  Prerequisite(s):

COMM 254.course_description: FA. This course focuses on the theory and criticism of film and media storytelling, both fiction and nonfiction. Students critically engage with academic writing and criticism published in magazines, newspapers, and other media outlets with a focus on the relation and practice of theory and criticism.

COMM 255.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course offers an examination of the history, aesthetics, ethics, and cultural and institutional functions of documentary film and television.     Not offered in 2024-25.

COMM 263.course_description: SP. An introduction to the theory and practice of communication and conflict resolution. Students will investigate the dynamics of conflict, theories of communication relevant to conflict resolution, conflict resolution processes and strategies. Students will learn skills that will enable them to assume leadership roles in the resolution of conflict, whether in the workplace, in the church, in political forums or at the international level. This knowledge can be applied in a variety of contexts: friendships, small groups, families, church, workplace, and community.

COMM 265.course_description: This course examines both the theoretical and applied dimensions of leadership, focusing on the communicative aspects of leaders and leadership. Course content covers models of leadership, leadership styles, factors that impact the perceptions of leadership, leadership ethics, and many approaches to writing and speaking as a leader.     Not offered in 2024-25.

COMM 285.course_description: FA. In this course students will examine how and why organizations use public relations to influence various publics. The course emphasizes the historical development of public relations as well as current issues in these industries. We will cover the tools of communication and the numerous publics involved.

COMM 286.course_description: SP. In this course students will examine how and why organizations use Advertising as a discipline to build and promote brands. The course emphasizes the professional tools and strategies used in the industry to employ best practices in effective and ethical mass communication.

COMM 287.course_description: FA. This course covers the fundamentals of sports communication theory, research, and practice, enabling students to communicate well in a variety of sports environments. The course covers organizational and leadership communication in sports, sports and mass media and social media, sports and public relations and crisis communication, and sports communication and society. The course also teaches ethical and legal issues in sports communication practice. The final project involves creating an effective media or social media presence for a sports team.

COMM 290.course_description: FA, SP. An intermediate-level course in digital filmmaking. The course includes further development of technical and creative skills, with special emphasis on the on-set world of independent fiction filmmaking. The goal of the course is to prepare students for COMM 351, which may be taken as either Documentary or Fiction. The course also introduces students to the process by which films are produced, the aesthetic and ethical challenges that this process demands, and how Christians working in the media should respond to such demands.  Prerequisite(s):

COMM 305.course_description: FA. This course examines the theory and practice of persuasive communication. Topics include persuasion theory and research; ethics of persuasion; recognizing, employing, and resisting persuasive strategies; and the role of propaganda in society.  Examples for analysis are taken from religion, advertising, political campaigns, social movements, and democratic and totalitarian propaganda.

COMM 311.course_description: FA, SP. Through careful study and practice of informal logic and rhetoric, students will become effective advocates, opponents, and decision makers in any argument context. The course is a study and application of basic principles of argumentation and advocacy. This course focuses on the dynamics of oral argument-ethical dimensions, use of language, informal logic, use of evidence and appeals, structure, and interactions with other arguments. Through analysis and practice, students will learn not only how to argue within academic contexts but also how to apply argumentative reasoning to everyday communication.

COMM 316.course_description: FA, SP, alternate years. An introduction to the practice and theory of directing. Through readings, critical analysis of scripts, discussions, performance exercises, and critique of live and filmed performance, students develop an understanding of the directing process from the inception of the script to the final product. Students create a full directorial analysis of a script and produce several finished scenes, applying rehearsal techniques, working with actors and learning to enhance their own productions through careful criticism and thoughtful assessment of the art of directing.

COMM 322.course_description: FA, SP. Experienced students contribute specific media production skills to the creation of a film, radio, and/or television production in the context of an advanced student project or under the supervision of a staff and/or faculty advisor. Students may participate more than one semester, but no more than four semester hours may be applied toward major or graduation requirements. Requires proposal and permission of instructor for approved projects only.  Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.

COMM 330.course_description: SP. A study of the role of diverse forms of media in society and an examination of critical and cultural perspectives on media. The course examines the media as a source of influential narratives and offers an understanding of the relationship of media to democracy, capitalism, technology, audiences, media institutions, and economics.

COMM 346.course_description: FA. In this weekly seminar course, students reflect on how to work, relate, and communicate effectively in professional settings. Academic work includes weekly seminar participation, readings, journals, a presentation, and a professional portfolio.  Grading is based on these requirements as well as the internship supervisor’s evaluation. Students must intern in a professional setting (for-profit or non-profit) a minimum of 10 hours each week throughout the semester they are enrolled in the course. Before the semester begins, students should find an internship that fits with their professional interests and will provide them with opportunities for new learning under the supervision of an expert. In order to engage the various levels of learning that an internship affords, we require students to intern off-campus and prefer that they work on-site at an organization rather than telecommuting.  Prerequisite(s): junior or senior status, and a 2.5 GPA.

COMM 351.course_description: FA, SP. The intensive study and production of video in a particular style or genre. Thorough investigation of creative, ethical, and technical requirements will culminate in student productions of short films. Offered as fiction every spring semester, and as documentary in alternate fall semesters.  Prerequisite(s):

COMM 358.course_description: FA, SP. Teams of students complete department-approved media production projects over the course of two semesters (2 credit hours per semester, total 4 credit hours). This capstone experience gives students the opportunity to apply concepts and techniques acquired in prerequisite courses by developing and producing an independent media project. Students in this course lead a team that may include students participating via

COMM 361.course_description: SP. This course introduces students to the broad and complex field of health communication through the study of multi-disciplinary research, theory, and health communication practice in interpersonal, small group, organizational, and mass-mediated contexts. Through analyzing crucial contemporary health issues, ethical dilemmas, case studies, and creating a health intervention campaign, students explore the centrality of communication for increasing health literacy, decreasing unhealthy behavior, and closing the health care inequity gap.     Not offered in 2024-25.

COMM 362.course_description: SP. This course is designed to guide class members through the issues and research literature related to communication within and from organizations and small groups. We focus on approaches, theories, and research findings concerning conceptions of organizations, various traditions in the study of organizations, metaphors for organizational communication, culture and climate within organizations, group processes, leadership, socialization/assimilation/membership negotiation, power, motivation/performance, organizational innovation and change, team-based structures and alternative forms of organizing, and strategic organizational communication. The unit of analysis undergirding the course is the actions of individuals or groups within organizations, especially actors’ messages and symbolic interactions, as well as the behavior of entire organizations or sets of organizations. Although organizations are such an ever-present, taken-for-granted aspect of our lives, you may not have developed a full understanding of them. For this reason, this course includes activities and assignments designed to enhance appreciation and analysis of organizations and organizational communication. The course also addresses competencies needed to communicative effectively in organizations and those skills useful for aiding others in organizations to attain personal and organizational goals.     Not offered in 2024-25.

COMM 381.course_name: Topics in Film and Media History
COMM 381.course_description: FA. In-depth study of a major period, movement, national cinema, development, genre, director, or producer in film and media history. An exploration of film and media as a complex phenomenon, an art form, and technology-based medium of communication in the context of culture, technology, society, and economics. Each year’s offering alternates between an emphasis on the history of Hollywood film and an emphasis on the history of global cinemas. This course may be repeated as long as the topic is unique.

COMM 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

COMM 390.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Independent study of topics of interest to particular students, under the supervision of a member of the department.  Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.

COMM 395.course_description: Topic, readings, and assignments will be announced prior to the year offered. Designed for students from various majors.  Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.

COMM 398.course_description: SP. This course focuses on the intersection of communication, technology, and society. Students will investigate the history and functions of relevant communication technologies, theories of communicative practice, the ethics of communication technologies, the personal and social implications of communicating via technology, and current developments in communication technologies.

COMM 399.course_description: FA, SP. A focused study of selected topics in a discipline of communication (film, media, rhetoric, or theatre) that builds upon previous communication coursework, methods, and theories. Coursework involves lecture, discussion, seminar presentations, and the preparation of a major research paper or project.  Prerequisite(s): two advanced courses within the department, and junior or senior status.   Not offered in 2024-25.

COMM 500.course_description: This eight-week course will train students in the basic skills of audiovisual media design. Students will work hands-on with the essential technology and software to begin building the necessary skillsets to become fluent and engaging multimedia content producers.

COMM 501.course_description: A media production studio course which supports and facilitates student completion of media production work assigned in any of four corequisite courses:

COMM 510.course_description: A study of the principles of storytelling integrating theory, critique, and hands-on experience as a way of learning best practices and understanding what makes for effective multimedia storytelling. Students will learn to become intentional about leveraging the strengths of different media to communicate synergistically in ways that single-medium stories cannot and to grasp the crucial role of perspectives in storytelling and audience reception.  Prerequisite(s):

COMM 511.course_description: Audience research is significant for media organizations to find target consumers and formulate their communication strategies. This course intends to provide useful knowledge of audience research. It covers the current audience research methodologies and theories, the ratings industry and analysis processes. The major subjects of this course include sampling methods, data collection methods, quantitative methods, qualitative methods, the theories of audience behaviors, gross measures, cumulative measures, online audience research, and global audiences.

COMM 512.course_description: FA1. Students will learn about their ethical responsibilities as professional communicators. They will investigate the principles on which those obligations and responsibilities are based—including social and cultural values, Christian virtues, and professional standards. In addition, they will learn to exercise moral and ethical reasoning when confronted with challenging situations in their vocation.

COMM 513.course_description: FA2. Students will learn about their legal responsibilities as professional communicators. They will investigate the principles on which those obligations and responsibilities are based, including professional standards. In addition, they will learn to exercise moral and ethical reasoning when confronted with challenging situations in their vocation.

COMM 520.course_description: This course introduces students to the strategic planning process, communication strategies, and message creation involved in public relations. Students will learn how to develop, implement and evaluate public relations campaigns by examining case studies and creating an actual campaign. This course also focuses on the use of social media and other new media channels, examining how they can be employed to better serve the organization’s communication and relationship building needs. Students must enroll in

COMM 521.course_description: This course explores advertising as an institution in society and as a communication process. Designed as a comprehensive view of the subject, the course includes such topics as advertising history, regulation, communication theory and practice, the role of advertising in the marketing mix, the organization of the advertising agency, marketing/advertising research, and the creative uses of various advertising media. Students will assess strategy and participate in the formulation of an advertising campaign. Students must enroll in

COMM 522.course_description: Multimedia journalism skills are critical in today’s newsrooms as well as in journalism-adjacent settings such as public relations and advocacy. This course will provide instruction and application in the tools and techniques of journalism production across non-text platforms. Using audio, video, web development, photography, and more, this course will cover journalistic fundamentals such as story development, reporting techniques, and editing. Students must enroll in

COMM 550.course_description: This course provides students with applied agency experience in public relations, advertising, and/or multimedia journalism, using a variety of media and platforms to create content for real clients.  Prerequisite(s):

COMM 551.course_description: A media production studio course which supports and facilitates student completion of media production work assigned in

HNRS 212.course_description: FA, SP, as needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will address communication practices as problem-solving forms embedded within social contexts. While topics will vary from year to year, all iterations will pay particular attention to the modes—that is, the styles or postures—that circulate across the attention economies of modern societies, from digital platforms to everyday physical spaces. The interdisciplinary component will attend to how communication practices and modes are structured by conversations in other disciplines.  Prerequisite(s):

CS 100.course_description: FA. An introduction to the creation of interactive media for the World Wide Web. Coverage includes markup language, stylesheets, page layout and design principles, scripting, animation, multimedia and their representations, World Wide Web history and structure, social and ethical issues.    Lab fee: $115.

CS 104.course_description: FA. An introduction to problem solving and program design for engineering students. Coverage includes algorithmic thinking, problem decomposition, types and expressions, functions and parameter passing, control structures, I/O, simple data structures, and classes (including the use of inheritance).   Corequisite(s):

CS 106.course_name: Introduction to Scientific Computation and Modeling
CS 106.course_description: FA. An introduction to computing as a tool for science, emphasizing programming as a methodology for problem solving, quantitative data analysis, and simulation in science and mathematics. This includes in silico modeling of natural phenomena, precise specification of a problem, design of its algorithmic solution, testing, debugging, and maintaining software, using scripting to increase scientific productivity, and the use of existing scientific software libraries. A secondary emphasis is the discussion of breadth topics, including historical, theoretical, ethical and biblical perspectives on computing as a discipline. This course provides an alternative to

CS 106L.course_name: introduction to Scientific Computation and Modeling Lab

CS 108.course_description: FA, SP. An introduction to computing as a problem-solving discipline. A primary emphasis is on programming as a methodology for problem solving, including: the precise specification of a problem, the design of its solution, the encoding of that solution, and the testing, debugging and maintenance of programs. A secondary emphasis is the discussion of topics from the breadth of computing including historical, theoretical, ethical and biblical perspectives on computing as a discipline.   Corequisite(s):

CS 195.course_description: FA, SP. This seminar explores a range of current topics in computing, including topics in research and practice. Students intending to major in a computing-related field must take this course three times in their freshman and sophomore years.  Prerequisite(s): freshman or sophomore standing.

CS 212.course_description: FA. A systematic study of algorithms and their application to more advanced data structures, including trees, heaps, hash tables, and graphs. Algorithms and data structures are analyzed in their use of both time and space, and the choice of data structure in problem solving is studied. Techniques for algorithm design are introduced. Theoretical issues, such as optimality, best- and worst-case performance, and limitations of algorithms are studied, as well as implementation issues.  Prerequisite(s):

CS 214.course_description: SP. Design principles and implementation issues of contemporary programming languages. Topics covered include programming paradigms; the syntax and semantics of programming language constructs, including those that support concurrent, parallel, and distributed processing; translation of high-level languages to machine language; formal languages and the automata that recognize them. Several different languages are introduced and examined to illustrate these topics.  Prerequisite(s):

CS 232.course_description: SP. An introduction to the major concepts modern operating systems must address. Topics include operating system structure, processes and threads, inter-process communication and synchronization, scheduling, main and secondary memory management, file systems, networking, client-server systems, distributed systems.  Prerequisite(s):

CS 262.course_description: FA. A survey of software engineering principles including software project management, system and requirements analysis, the design and implementation of software and information systems, design patterns, software quality assurance and testing, and software maintenance.  Prerequisite(s):

CS 295.course_description: FA, SP. This seminar explores a range of current topics in computing, including topics in research and practice. It is a continuation of

CS 300.course_description: FA, SP, select years. Advanced study of selected topics of current interest in computer science. Topics vary by year. Consult the instructor or the department website for the specific topic the current offering. This course may be repeated for credit if the special topics differ.  Prerequisite(s): varying; see department website.  Lab fee: $15.

CS 312.course_description: FA, alternate years. An introduction to first-order logic, computability and computational complexity. Topics covered include soundness and completeness of a formal proof system, computability and non-computability, and computational complexity with an emphasis on NP-completeness. Crosslisted as

CS 320.course_description: SP, select years. Principles of computer design, instruction set design principles, instruction-level parallelism, cache principles, and multiprocessor systems.    Lab fee: $15.

CS 326.course_name: Embedded Systems and the Internet of Things
CS 326.course_description: SP, alternate years. An introduction to topics in embedded systems and the Internet of Things (IoT) including hardware and software considerations for special-purpose computing applications that interact with the physical world. Hardware topics include microcontrollers, I/O interfacing, sensors, and actuators. Software topics include scheduling and real-time considerations, IoT network protocols, the Web of things, and embedded programming. Additional topics include discussions of related social and ethical issues such as security, privacy, reliability, and the impact of automation. Lectures will be combined with hands-on lab exercises and a final project.  Prerequisite(s):

CS 332.course_description: FA, alternate years. This course investigates advanced topics in the field of computer networking. Students will explore the implementation of TCP, IPv6, routing protocols, software-defined networking, and other advanced topics. Issues of justice and a reformed Christian perspective on network access will be explored.  Prerequisite(s):

CS 336.course_description: FA, alternate years. An introduction to software development for websites using common platforms and frameworks. In addition to development, topics include common vulnerabilities and means of defending against them, web user interfaces and usability, and practical, legal, and ethical issues associated with building and administering websites.  Prerequisite(s):

KOR 101.course_description: FA. An introductory course in which basic conversational and grammatical skills are taught. The course is based on a communicative approach, aiming for students to be able to communicate in Korean at a basic level and also to have a structural awareness of the language. Major cultural aspects of Korea are also studied in a Christian context.

LATN 101.course_description: FA, as needed. For students who have had only one year of high school Latin or no Latin at all. This course will teach students the essentials of grammar and a basic vocabulary, and an appreciation of the Latin language, its literature, and its importance in today’s culture. Sententiae from the principal Latin authors will be read. Offered upon sufficient demand; interested students should contact the Historical Studies department chair.     Not offered in 2024-25.

LATN 102.course_description: SP, as needed. A continuation of

MGMT 531.course_description: FA2. The marketing management process (a.k.a corporate marketing or strategic marketing) is critical at all levels of the organization, regardless of the title applied to the activity. This course focuses on formulating and implementing marketing management strategies and tactics and relating marketing principles to consumer and business actions. The course also includes opportunities to develop a marketing strategy and select appropriate tactics to successfully implement the strategy and deliver value to the target market.   Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program.

MGMT 533.course_description: SP1. Organizational leaders are expected to make effective data-driven decisions. This course focuses on the development and use of accounting information in the analysis and decision-making process. This course includes financial accounting and managerial accounting topics. The financial accounting topics include Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), asset valuation, measurement of liabilities, and income determination. The managerial accounting topics include cost-volume-profit analysis, differential analysis, and budgeting. In addition to using accounting information to make effective decisions, the course focuses on communicating (orally, visually, and in writing) to a variety of stakeholders.   Prerequisite(s): admission to the graduate business program.

MGMT 535.course_description: SP2. This course begins with a broad overview of operations and supply chain systems with a special emphasis on understanding lean methodology. Through integration of a supply chain simulation students will be utilizing advanced analytical tools to make strategic supply chain decisions. Decisions, strategies, and course teaching are provided with global context to simulate typical real-world scenarios.

MGMT 537.course_description: SU2. Organizations are often challenged in determining a capital structure that results in minimizing the cost of capital. This course focuses on the “why” and “how” companies raise debt and equity capital from investors, and considerations necessary to make informed decisions to invest capital in future growth opportunities. Accounting information and financial analyses are used and performed to assist with the above decisions and to advocate with company stakeholders.  Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program.   Not offered in 2024-25.

MGMT 542.course_name: Leadership: Service, Influence, and Transformation I
MGMT 542.course_description: SU2. This course provides students with an overview of authentic and servant leadership. The focus is on providing the critical skills of self-leadership toward personal and professional goals as the context for studying service, influence, and intentional development and growth. Students learn about individual differences and about themselves using assessment materials, analytical tools, and theory and will develop plans that support sustained growth toward personal objectives. Students are guided in a personal vision process and learn through case studies of authentic and servant leadership.

MGMT 543.course_name: Leadership: Service, Influence, and Transformation II
MGMT 543.course_description: SU. This course provides students with an overview of authentic and servant leadership. The focus is on providing the critical skills of self-leadership toward personal and professional goals as the context for studying service, influence, and intentional development and growth. Students learn about individual differences and about themselves using assessment materials, analytical tools, and theory and will develop plans that support sustained growth toward personal objectives. Students are guided in a personal vision process and learn through case studies of authentic and servant leadership.  Prerequisite(s):

MGMT 544.course_description: FA. This course prepares students to provide formal and informal leadership to groups, teams, and organizations. Students learn to design and implement effective team processes and diagnose team performance and the threats and opportunities teams face. Students gain an understanding of the relevant frameworks for organizational design, culture, and change and will practice applying these frameworks using assignments and case studies.     Not offered in 2024-25.

MGMT 546.course_name: Leading Organizations: Structure, Culture, and Change
MGMT 546.course_description: SP2. Healthy and successful organizations are structured in alignment with their strategy, have strong, values-based cultures, and are able to adapt to change. This course will enhance an understanding of life inside organizations through an interdisciplinary examination of common organizational practices such as organizational structure, culture differentiation and internal integration, culture typologies, as well as leadership attributes and styles. The course is designed to increase effectiveness in dealing with multiple aspects of organizational change—by understanding conditions that may require it, increasing awareness of multiple ways that organizations change, managing change, receiving and participating in it, and understanding approaches and responses to change.  Prerequisite(s): Prerequisite: admission into the graduate business program.   Not offered in 2024-25.

MGMT 548.course_description: SP2. This course orients students to the ethical imperatives of leadership in contemporary organizations. Ethical leadership theory provides a framework for connecting personal faith and identity resources with best practices in ethics and compliance management; together, these prepare students to realize improved business conduct, and enhanced diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging (DEIB) in their organizations. Students develop their own contextual agendas for ethical leadership through reflective writing exercises.

MGMT 552.course_description: SU2. This course provides students with an overview and awareness of how successful organizations are able to navigate times of high uncertainty and to proactively “design for change.” Focus is on students gaining the knowledge of the environment, culture, and processes needed to design for innovation and resiliency. Students also learn about individual differences and about themselves and the part they can play in their organization being one designed for innovation and resiliency in uncertain times.

MGMT 553.course_description: SU This course builds on the cohort experience and the innovation strategy coursework by helping students think through how they will personally move forward in cultivating innovation and resiliency in their organization. Students further develop their “innovation persona” and make a connection to how it can be applied in their organization. Students gain an understanding of the soft skills needed to cultivate innovation and resiliency in their organization.  Prerequisite(s):

MGMT 554.course_description: SU. This course is a topics course, which features a different business innovation strategy topic each time it is offered. Possible topics include disruptive innovation, human-centered design, innovation case studies, and other “timeless” topics, as well as current hot topics.

MGMT 555.course_description: FA1. This course is a foundational learning environment for students to acquire business innovation and strategy frameworks and tools. An important part of the learning comes from applying with teammates the frameworks and tools to an actual situation of a for-profit company or nonprofit organization that participates in the courses as a course sponsor.

MKTG 601.course_description: SU1. This course introduces the strategic marketing management process to prepare students to be successful marketing managers by learning to craft and execute marketing strategies that contribute to organizational success. Students take a deeper dive into strategic areas of competitive market analysis, segmentation, branding, distribution channels, pricing, and integrated marketing communication. The course uses both a textbook and cases and focuses on applying concepts into practice. In addition, students are challenged to critically evaluate the above from a Christian perspective.  Prerequisite(s):

RFLA 101.course_description: FA, every fourth year. Students will engage in an interactive curriculum to learn about income, expenses, assets, liabilities, and risk management. Students will also learn how to utilize technology to assist them in the management of their daily finances, addressing the areas of employment, housing, transportation, education, entertainment, and saving for their future. They will explore the value of price comparing through hands-on learning activities, learn different ways to shop for goods and services, identify the value of planned shopping versus impulse buying, and explore consumer rights.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education

RFLA 102.course_description: FA, every fourth year. Students will demonstrate responsible stewardship of personal resources through budget planning, maintenance of a budget, and investigation of banking, debit, and credit practices. Using real-life financial scenarios, students will learn to build and maintain credit scores, find out what it means to qualify for a mortgage, utilize insurance, and work toward a savings goal. Students will practice setting up a bank account, use online banking, pay bills online, and read and understand their own paycheck. Finally, students will learn how to adjust and improve their budget as their financial situation changes.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 111.course_description: SP, every fourth year. Students will explore strategies for making and keeping friends and delve into peer-to-peer communication using interactive lessons that address finding common interests; using humor; trading information; sharing the conversation; and initiating, maintaining, and ending a conversation. Students will learn multiple forms of communication, evaluate the appropriateness of the communication form to a given scenario, and apply methods to their daily interactions. Students will be introduced to different forms of social media and will be able to identify positive and effective ways to utilize social media for communication.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 112.course_description: SP, every fourth year. Students will learn that what happens around us influences our thoughts, feelings, reactions, and responses. Using social mapping and strategies to manage social stressors, students will gain the skills needed to better navigate the social world, communicate with one another, and develop stronger social competencies. Additionally, students will focus on digital communication skills, including use of cell phones, text, social media, and email, as tools for advocacy and growing positive relationships. They will identify and apply practices for safe, positive, and effective digital communication for navigating a complex social world.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 121.course_name: Personal Management and Success in the Workplace
RFLA 121.course_description: FA, every fourth year. Students will explore their own identity and the roles they hold within family, school, work, and faith communities. They will delve into attribution theory and identify ways that individual choices can support success in the workplace. By using a decision-making process; goal writing, assessment; and exploration of self, students will develop personal agency and empowerment to pursue their goals for lifelong career and vocation. Students will discover, through real life scenarios, the importance of perseverance and drawing on trusted members of family, social, and faith communities to support goal attainment.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 122.course_description: FA, every fourth year. Students will discover how to make choices that lead to flourishing in their social, work, and spiritual lives. They will delve into employment readiness, soft skills, the employment process, teamwork, and exploring what it means to reflect Christ’s character in the workplace. Students will grow their agency, advocacy, and action planning skills to reach future career goals through self-assessment of personal priorities, application of the decision-making process, utilization of time management skills, life mapping, and applying the tools they have learned in support of positive work-life balance.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 131.course_description: SP, every fourth year. Students will explore personal priorities that impact choosing a place to live as well as solve common, real-world problems that may arise while living on their own. They will develop skills and tools needed for independent living, including planning a weekly menu, shopping for groceries, preparing healthy meals based on a budget, caring for personal clothing, and purchasing new clothes. They will learn common cooking vocabulary and apply these to their daily meal preparation. They will practice skills needed to maintain their home and make it a place that is safe, functional, and comfortable.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 132.course_description: SP, every fourth year. Students will explore practices for maintaining their own physical and mental health, including daily health maintenance; avoiding health problems; improving exercise, sleep, eating, and stress management habits; accessing medical help; and utilizing health insurance. They will identify and practice safe self-administration of medication and maintain a safety plan for avoiding health hazards. Students will discuss the importance of making healthy decisions regarding sexual relationships. Furthermore, they will identify the signs of emotional, sexual, and physical abuse and identify strategies, information, resources, and steps needed to end abuse.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 153.course_description: SP, alternate years. Students will explore the inquiry process by framing a research question in a self-selected area of interest. Students will practice skills for obtaining reputable sources in pursuit of answers to their query. They will compile their completed research; determine the best methods to communicate the information in formal and informal settings; design and create their own research presentation; and share it with peers, professors, and community members at a research fair on campus.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 163.course_description: FA. Students will be supported through teaching and mentorship as they enter and acclimate to college life. They will be introduced to campus life, create a safety plan, and learn about positive learning and college behaviors. Students will also develop study skills and find their place of belonging on a college campus.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 164.course_description: SP. Students are supported as they prepare to launch from college life to the real world. They develop a portfolio complete with resume, letters of recommendation, and overviews of projects they have completed throughout their college experience. Students will connect with vocational rehabilitation services and pursue their self-determined employment and independent living goals. Students create their final person-centered plan and explore available community supports.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

RFLA 380.course_description: FA, SP. This course is intended to provide students with career exploration experiences in a supported, campus or community-based setting. Each student will have the chance to work in a specific job placement in the career field related to their individualized employment goals and/or selected course of study. Students are expected to complete the required internship hours within the job placement selected. This course may be repeated for credit.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permssion from the school of education.

RFLA 390.course_description: FA, SP. Students choose a topic that they would like to explore. Topics could include, but are not limited to literacy, current events, or extending a research inquiry. Student and faculty will collaborate to create an individualized curriculum designed to explore the topic of interest or a specific skill that may be needed for a future career. This course may be repeated for credit.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Ready for Life Academy or permission from the dean of education.

MKTG 301.course_description: FA, SP. A study of the principles and strategies for planning and controlling marketing programs, including the market research, product development, pricing, promotion, and distribution of ideas, goods, services, experiences, and values that attempts to satisfy individual and organizational needs and objectives. Includes real-world learning projects.  Prerequisite(s):

MKTG 302.course_description: FA. An in-depth look at the processes involved when consumers purchase and use products, study of internal and external influences for purchase, and implications for marketing research and marketing strategy. Includes real-world learning research projects. This course is required for Marketing Majors at Calvin.  Prerequisite(s):

MKTG 303.course_description: FA. This class uses a relationship selling model that builds value and benefits both the buying and selling parties. Students will learn communications skills useful in making informative and persuasive presentations. Course topics include prospecting, how to make positive first impressions, presentation skills, managing objections, negotiating, reaching win-win decisions, time management, team-selling, sales force management, and serving customers. This class is required for a Marketing-Professional Selling concentration and is an elective in other Marketing concentrations.  Prerequisite(s):

MKTG 310.course_description: SP. A study of marketing theory, strategy, and tactics. This course is research based and includes real-world learning projects.  Prerequisite(s):

MKTG 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

MATH 100.course_description: FA. An introduction to the nature and variety of mathematics results and methods, mathematical models and their applications, and to the interaction between mathematics and culture. Not open to mathematics and natural science majors.

MATH 110.course_description: FA. A course in algebra and elementary functions to prepare students to succeed in the calculus sequence. Topics include functions and their graphs, solutions of equations, polynomial functions, trigonometric functions and their inverses, exponential functions, and logarithmic functions.

MATH 132.course_name: Calculus for Management, Life, and Social Sciences
MATH 132.course_description: SP. Functions, limits, and derivatives. Applications of derivatives to maximum-minimum problems, exponential and logarithmic functions, integrals, and functions of several variables. Not open to those who have completed

MATH 171.course_description: FA, SP. This course serves as an introduction to calculus. Topics include functions, limits, derivatives, applications of derivatives, and integrals. Historical and philosophical aspects of calculus are integrated with the development of the mathematical ideas, providing a sense of the context in which calculus was developed.  Prerequisite(s): four years of college preparatory mathematics or the equivalent.

MATH 172.course_description: FA, SP. Techniques of integration, applications of integration, infinite sequences and series, parametric equations and polar coordinates, vectors, and the geometry of space.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of C- or better in

MATH 190.course_description: FA. An introduction in seminar format to several different topics in mathematics not otherwise part of the undergraduate program. Topics vary by semester, but will include both classical and recent results and both theoretical and applied topics. The goals of the course are to acquaint students with the breadth of mathematics and to provide opportunity for students interested in mathematics to study these topics together. All first-year students interested in mathematics (regardless of prospective major program) are welcome to register. This course will be graded on a credit/no-credit basis.

MATH 221.course_name: The Real Number System and Methods for Elementary School Teachers
MATH 221.course_description: FA, SP. This course provides prospective elementary school teachers with background needed for teaching elementary mathematics. Both content and methodology relevant to school mathematics are considered. Topics covered include the real number system and its sub-systems. Pedagogical issues addressed include the nature of mathematics and of mathematics learning and the role of problem solving and the impact of technology in the elementary school mathematics curriculum.  Prerequisite(s):

An introduction to solutions and applications of first and second-order ordinary differential equations including Laplace transforms, elementary linear algebra, systems of linear differential equations, numerical methods and non-linear equations.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of C- or better in

MATH 301.course_description: SP, alternate years. A study of Euclidean and hyperbolic geometries from an axiomatic viewpoint. Additional topics include transformations, geometric constructions (facilitated through software), and the construction of models for geometries.  Prerequisite(s):

MATH 305.course_name: The Geometry and Topology of Manifolds
MATH 305.course_description: FA, alternate years. An introduction to the study of manifolds, including both the geometric topology and the differential geometry of manifolds. The emphasis is on low-dimensional manifolds, especially curves and surfaces. Topics include the topology of subsets of Euclidean space, curves and surfaces in Euclidean space, the topological classification of compact connected surfaces, smooth curves and surfaces, curvature, geodesics, the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem and the geometry of space.  Prerequisite(s):

MATH 312.course_description: FA, alternate years. An introduction to first-order logic, computability and computational complexity. Topics covered include soundness and completeness of a formal proof system, computability and non-computability, and computational complexity with an emphasis on NP-completeness. Crosslisted as

MATH 324.course_name: Teaching Mathematics in Elementary Grades: Internship I
MATH 324.course_description: FA, SP. This course provides opportunities to examine issues and enact pedagogical practices that engage Pre-K through 6th-grade learners in mathematics and develop productive mathematical dispositions. Learner-centered and equitable instruction, curriculum, assessment, and partnerships with caregivers as they relate to mathematics are examined and practiced. Teacher candidates in this course will reflect upon the relationship between one’s faith/worldview and teaching of mathematics. The course is taken concurrently with field placements in grades PK-3 and/or 3-6.  Prerequisite(s):

MATH 327.course_name: Mathematics Content and Teaching Methods for Middle Grades
MATH 327.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course examines best practices in the teaching and learning of mathematics for the middle grades. Relevant mathematics concepts for these grade levels will be explored. This course is generally taken during the junior year and is required for education majors seeking middle and/or high school licensure to teach mathematics.  Prerequisite(s): Internship I (

MATH 331.course_description: FA, alternate years. Qualitative study of linear and nonlinear ordinary differential equations and discrete time maps including stability analysis, bifurcations, fractal structures and chaos; applications to biology, chemistry, physics, and engineering.  Prerequisite(s):

MATH 333.course_description: FA, alternate years. An introduction to partial differential equations and their applications. Topics include mathematical modeling with PDEs, nondimensionalization, orthogonal expansions, solution methods for linear initial and boundary value problems, asymptotic expansions, and numerical solution of PDEs.  Prerequisite(s):

MATH 335.course_description: Offered occasionally. Theory and practice of computational procedures Including principles of error analysis and scientific computation, root-finding, polynomial Interpolation, splines, numerical Integration, applications to ordinary differential equations, computational matrix algebra, orthogonal polynomials, least square approximations, and other applications.  Prerequisite(s):

MATH 355.course_description: SP. Vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues and eigenvectors, inner product spaces, spectral theory, singular values and pseudoinverses, canonical forms, and applications.  Prerequisite(s): either

MATH 359.course_name: Mathematics Content and Teaching Methods for High School
MATH 359.course_description: FA, alternate years. A course in perspectives on, principles of, and practices in the teaching of mathematics at the secondary level.

MATH 380.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course explores the historical development of some of the basic concepts of modern mathematics. It includes an examination of significant issues and controversies, philosophical perspectives, and problems on which mathematicians have focused throughout history.  Prerequisite(s): two MATH courses numbered 231 or above.

MATH 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in Math department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the Math department.

MATH 385.course_description: FA, SP, as needed. Advanced study of selected topics in mathematics. Consult instructor for course information. This course may be repeated for credit provided the topic is different.  Prerequisite(s): a mathematics course numbered 231 or above. Some topics may have additional requirements.

MATH 390.course_description: FA, SP. Independent study of topics of interest to particular students under supervision of a member of the department staff. Open to qualified students with permission of the department chair.

MATH 391.course_description: FA, SP. Meets weekly for an hour for the presentation of various topics in Mathematics, computer science, and related disciplines by students, faculty, and visiting speakers.  Prerequisite(s): two 200-level courses in mathematics.

MATH 395.course_description: FA, SP. The course requirements include an expository or research paper and an oral presentation on a selected topic in mathematics. Open to qualified students with the permission of the chair.

MGMT 342.course_description: This course will provide students with an overview and awareness of the social, cognitive, and psychological processes characterizing authentic and servant leadership. Focus will be on providing students the critical skills of self-leadership towards personal and professional goals as the context for studying service, influence, and intentional development and growth. Students will learn about individual differences and about themselves using assessments, analytical tools, and theory to develop action plans that will support sustained growth towards personal objectives. Students will also learn through multiple case studies of authentic and servant leadership.

ML 101.course_description: This course prepares leaders in the church to be faithful and effective stewards of the Word by acquainting them with the basic content and principal theme of each book of the Old Testament; the historical, geographical, and cultural backgrounds to the Old Testament; its introductory hermeneutical principles; and its continuing relevance.

ML 102.course_description: This course prepares leaders in the church to be faithful and effective stewards of the Word by acquainting them with the basic content and principal theme of each book of the New Testament; the historical, geographical, and cultural backgrounds to the New Testament; its introductory hermeneutical principles; and its continuing relevance.

ML 121.course_description: The process of spiritual formation is intentionally engaged so that habits developed throughout students’ theological education will form them for ministry.

ML 122.course_description: The Practice of Discipleship is a designed to introduce students to the grand vision of God’s Mission and the implications for embodied discipleship. Attention will be given to vital biblical themes which give shape to the day to day and personal acts of discipleship. Students will learn about the grand narrative of God’s Mission, important theological concepts such as covenant, shalom, the biblical use of power, discipleship and Jesus’ teaching on many of these issues. Additionally, students will engage in spiritual disciplines including internal and external practices. Finally, students will grow to better understand the interconnectedness and vital relationship between individual acts of discipleship and the contribution which these make to the overall mission of God in our world.

ML 221.course_description: This course will aid students in constructing a biblical, theological, and practical framework for understanding and implementing pastoral care. Students will begin to formulate and embrace their own pastoral identity and to create a foundational corpus of skills and competencies that address various modes of pastoral care. The pastoral skills and competencies that are addressed in this course will assist students in developing contextual perspective, understanding the complexities of human experience, and appropriating theological and biblical perspectives, all in the service of providing effective pastoral care within a relational paradigm.

ML 321.course_description: An introduction to the principles and practices of vital and faithful worship leadership. The course explores biblical and historical perspectives on worship practices and gives students practice at several basic worship planning and leading skills.

ML 322.course_description: This course prepares students to serve as pastors or mentors within the context of the faith community. Special consideration is given to the settings in which pastors and mentors engage in helping relationships, the need for appropriate boundaries to protect the dignity of both those seeking counsel and those offering to help them, and the place of helping relationships in the broader horizon of institutions and communities beyond the pastoral context.  Prerequisite(s):

ML 323.course_description: Equips students to provide effective pastoral leadership in forming communities of disciples, and integrates a biblical theology of leadership with personal reflection, discernment of contexts, and practical leadership skills.

ML 326.course_description: This course will explore restorative justice and the ideas that form its foundation, question its strengths and shortcomings, examine restorative practices , and investigate opportunities to put the theory into practice. Moreover, we will finetune our exploration of restorative justice from a religious point of view, and more specifically from a Christian point of view. We will note that several world religions provide a vision of what we are calling “restorative justice,” and that Christianity puts a fine point on restorative justice as a form of “reconciliation.” We will further explore how the church models a type of “commmunity of reconciliation” and as a model can inform how we might want to shape other social spaces into communities of restorative justice and reconciliation. For sections taught for the Calvin Prison Initiative, the social space we will consider is the Richard Handlon Correctional Facility. To that end, we will briefly take up issues of crime and punishment in the United States and relocate them in the realm of restorative justice and communities of reconciliation. On the Knollcrest campus, the social space we will consider is a local neighborhood or community context.

HNRS 213.course_description: SP, alternate years. Students will deepen their knowledge of musical traditions, attending to the social contexts that shape and animate different artistic forms and practices. Music will be explored as a mode of artistic expression and a creative means of problem-solving related to societal needs and values. Iterations of the course will work to cultivate listening as a form of discernment for understanding communities as well as ourselves more fully.  Prerequisite(s):

MUSC 100.course_name: Music Theory Fundamentals in Global Context
MUSC 100.course_description: FA, SP. An introduction to Western music theory fundamentals such as pitch, scales and modes, key signatures, intervals, triads, meter, and form. The course will consider how Western musical patterns relating time, pitch, and structure are similar to and different from musical patterns in the non-West. It will also provide an opportunity to reflect on how and why humans create patterns out of sound and why God created us to be musical.

MUSC 103.course_description: FA, SP. This is an introductory course in historically-informed critical and perceptive listening to music. The relationship between musical style and culture is examined as is the forming of style by the manner in which the ingredients and elements of music are employed. Western art music is emphasized but also included are contemporary popular music and either pre-modern music or non-Western music. No previous musical training is required.

MUSC 106.course_description: FA. A survey course of American music for domestic, church, concert, and entertainment uses, emphasizing folk, classical, and popular music from a variety of American musical traditions. These traditions include hymns, spirituals, gospel, blues, jazz, rock, hip-hop, and classical music. No musical training is required.     Not offered in 2024-25.

MUSC 107.course_description: SP. This is a study of select musical cultures of Asia, the Middle East, Africa, Europe, and the Americas, with a focus on their various musical styles (traditional and contemporary) and the roles of music in these cultures. No previous musical training is required.

MUSC 108.course_description: FA. A study of tonal harmony and part-writing, covering triads, inversions, phrases, cadences, nonharmonic tones, and secondary dominants.  Prerequisite(s):

MUSC 111.course_description: FA. Functional realization at the keyboard of musical-theoretical concepts covered in

MUSC 112.course_description: SP. Functional realization at the keyboard of musical-theoretical concepts covered in

MUSC 203.course_description: FA. A survey course exploring the historical development, stylistic variety, and cultural significance of Western popular music from the mid-nineteenth century to today, including folk music, minstrelsy, blues, jazz, musicals, rock, hip-hop, and related genres. No previous musical training is required.

MUSC 213.course_description: FA. Provides instruction in musicianship skills, including sight singing, dictation, rhythm reading, and improvisation. Usually taken concurrently with

MUSC 225.course_description: SP. An introduction to computer-based music technology, including music notation (Sibelius), virtual instruments and synthesis (using Native Instruments software), and MIDI sequencing, audio recording, and editing (using ProTools and Logic Pro).  Prerequisite(s):

MUSC 236.course_description: FA, alternate years.
