Students will assume basic roles of the professional nurse and utilize skills of assessment, communication, critical thinking, and nursing process to design and provide empirically based nursing care to individuals in a variety of acute care and community-based settings. NURS 309 will be graded as pass/fail (CR - completed as required/NC - not completed).   Prerequisite(s): limited to students who have been admitted to the upper division nursing major.  Course fee: $1,389.

NURS 309L.course_name: Community and Mental Health Nursing Simulation

NURS 321.course_name: Theory: Nursing Care of Pregnant Women and Newborns
NURS 321.course_description: SP. In this theory course, students will explore the foundations of caring for pregnant women, newborns, and women of childbearing age within the context of the community and health care system. Students will learn pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 322.course_name: Practicum: Nursing Care of Pregnant Women and Newborns
NURS 322.course_description: SP. This course provides the student with an off-campus practicum experience providing nursing care for pregnant women, newborns, and women of childbearing age across the continuum of care using a variety of acute and community settings.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 323.course_description: SP. In this theory course, students will explore the foundations of caring for infants, children, and adolescents within the context of the community and the health care team. Students will learn pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 324.course_description: SP. This practicum course provides the student with an off-campus practicum experience providing nursing care to infants, children, and adolescents across the continuum of care using a variety of acute and community settings.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 325.course_name: Lab, Sim, and Clinical Reasoning Sem: Care of PWI & Children
NURS 325.course_description: SP. This course, Nursing Lab, Simulation, and Clinical Reasoning Seminar for Care of Pregnant Women, Newborns, and Children, weaves together lab, simulation, and a clinical reasoning seminar. Informed by the Reformed Christian worldview, students will demonstrate progress towards achieving competency in clinical judgement, integrating informatics and healthcare technologies to promote safe care and promoting personal wellness while caring for individuals and populations. Students will practice within health promotion / disease prevention and chronic disease spheres of care.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 327.course_name: Theory: Pregnant Women, Infants, Children, and Adolescents
NURS 327.course_description: SP. This theory course will focus on health promotion and health protection concepts for pregnant women, infants, children, and adolescents in the context of their families and communities. Topics will include primary, secondary, and tertiary health protection and health promotion from the perspective of community based care.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 328.course_name: Strategies: Pregnant Women, Infants, Children, and Adolescents
NURS 328.course_description: SP. This course provides students with opportunities to develop health promotion and health protection strategies in caring for pregnant women, infants, children, and adolescents. Students will develop knowledge and skills in health and cultural assessment, communication, nutrition, pharmacology, psychomotor activities, and nursing informatics systems related to care of pregnant women, infants, children, and adolescents.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 328L.course_name: Strategies: Pregnant Women, Infants, Children, and Adolescents Lab

NURS 329.course_name: Practicum: Pregnant Women, Infants, Children, and Adolescents
NURS 329.course_description: SP. The student will utilize the nursing process to promote and protect the health of pregnant women, infants, children, and adolescents in the context of their families and communities. Students will spend six weeks with pregnant women and infants and six weeks with children and adolescents in both acute care settings and a variety of community settings. Students will have opportunities to apply knowledge of health promotion and primary, secondary, and tertiary health protection strategies. The focus of the course is on engagement in clinical decision making skills and problem solving in working with these clients. NURS 329 will be graded as pass/fail (CR - completed as required / NC - not completed).  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 329L.course_name: Pregnant Women, Infants, Children, and Adolescents Simulation

NURS 351.course_description: FA. This course will focus on caring for adults in the context of their communities, the health care team, and health care systems. Students will learn pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions, including restorative care.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 352.course_description: FA. This practicum course provides the student with an off-campus practicum experience providing nursing care to adults across the continuum of care using a variety of acute and community settings.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 353.course_name: Theory: Nursing Care of Complex Adults
NURS 353.course_description: FA. This course will continue to focus on caring for adults in the context of their communities, the health care team, and health care systems. Students will learn pharmacologic and non-pharmacologic strategies to prevent and care for acute and chronic conditions, including trauma, comorbidity, palliative, and end-of-life care.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 355.course_name: Lab, Sim, and Clinical Reasoning Sem: Adults
NURS 355.course_description: FA. This course weaves together lab, simulation, and a clinical reasoning seminar.  Informed by the Reformed Christian worldview, students will demonstrate competency in implementing a holistic plan of care, communicating with the health care team, implementing quality and safety principles, and applying health care technology and informatics. Students will practice within chronic disease, restorative, hospice, and palliative spheres of care.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 357.course_name: Theory: Young, Middle, and Older Adults
NURS 357.course_description: FA. This course will focus on the concepts of health promotion and health protection for young, middle, and older adults in the context of their families and communities. Topics will include primary, secondary, and tertiary health protection and health promotion including community based care and role development. The student will learn about partnerships with adults to actively promote health as well as protecting health during times of acute and chronic illness.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 358.course_name: Strategies: Young, Middle, and Older Adults
NURS 358.course_description: FA. This course provides the student with opportunities to develop health promotion and primary, secondary, and tertiary health protection strategies in care delivery for adults. Students will develop knowledge and skills in health and cultural assessment of adults, pharmacology, communication, nutrition, psychomotor activities, and nursing informatics systems related to care of adult clients.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 359.course_name: Practicum: Young, Middle, and Older Adults
NURS 359.course_description: FA. The student will utilize the nursing process to promote and protect the health of adults in the context of their families and communities. Students care for young, middle, and older adults in acute care settings and visit a variety of community settings. Students will have opportunities to apply knowledge of health promotion and primary, secondary, and tertiary health protection theory and strategies. The focus of the course is on engagement in clinical decision making skills and problem solving with adult clients. NURS 359 will be graded pass/fail (CR - completed as required/NC - not completed).   Prerequisite(s):

NURS 359L.course_name: Young, Middle, and Older Adult Simulation

NURS 360.course_name: Exploring Culture, Health, Faith, and Nursing
NURS 360.course_description: WI. This elective, off-campus nursing course is offered during the January winter-intensive period. The goal of the course is to explore a culture outside of West Michigan. Students will experience the intersection of culture, health, and faith in the culture of the course location. Students will visit healthcare facilities, interact with nurses, and have cultural experiences.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the nursing major.  Travel-related fees may apply. Not offered in 2024-25.

NURS 371.course_description: SP. This theory course will focus on caring for the community as client. Students will learn about the role of the public health nurse and how community assessment, epidemiology, health policy, and disaster preparedness can be used to promote population health and system effectiveness.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 372.course_description: SP. This practicum course will provide students the opportunity to care for the community as client. Students will spend time in one of the nursing department’s partner neighborhoods, seeking to address health disparities through listening to community voice. Students will also learn how to use principles of community-based participatory research to promote population health.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 373.course_name: Theory: Leadership and Management in Nursing
NURS 373.course_description: SP. This theory course is focused on leadership/management principles used by the professional nurse and their impact on health outcomes and system effectiveness. Students will demonstrate team-based case management to deliver safe, high-quality care.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 374.course_name: Practicum: Leadership and Management in Nursing
NURS 374.course_description: SP. This precepted practicum course will provide students the opportunity to assume the role of the nurse and apply principles of leadership and management to nursing practice.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 375.course_name: Sim and Clinical Reasoning Sem: Individuals and Populations
NURS 375.course_description: SP. This course, Final Simulation and Clinical Reasoning Seminar for Care of Individuals and Populations, provides students the opportunity to synthesize learning from prior semesters as they care for individuals and populations. Students will demonstrate competency in ethical decision making, collaborating with the interprofessional team, providing coordinated care in partnership with community, and applying quality improvement principles in care delivery. Students will practice across all four spheres of care.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 377.course_name: Theory: Community Focused Nursing and Leadership/Management
NURS 377.course_description: SP. This theory course is focused on health promotion/health protection for the community as client and leadership/management principles that are used by the professional nurse.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 378.course_name: Strategies: Synthesis of Nursing Care across the Lifespan
NURS 378.course_description: SP. In this nursing laboratory course, students will synthesize techniques of health promotion and health protection for and with individuals, families, and groups across the lifespan in complex health situations. Students will focus on critical thinking and decision making principles in nursing practice. The course will include multifaceted, laboratory simulations that require students to analyze and synthesize assessment data and design care with other health care professionals. Students will integrate their knowledge of the Christian perspective, core virtues, and diversity into the care that they design.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 379.course_name: Practicum: Community Focused Nursing and Leadership/Management
NURS 379.course_description: SP. This course will afford students the opportunity to partner with communities as well as interdisciplinary groups of health care providers for the purpose of promoting and protecting health. Partnerships with communities offer opportunities for the student to assist the community to develop the best health care possible for diverse cultural groups. Partnerships with interdisciplinary staff members allow for principles of management and leadership to be integrated into nursing practice. NURS 379 will be graded as pass/fail (CR - completed as required / NC - not completed).  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 379L.course_name: Community Focused Nursing and Leadership/Management Simulation

NURS 380.course_description: SP. This reflective course will lead the student into inquiry about the relationship between Christian faith and the discipline of nursing. Students will examine how the Reformed Christian worldview and interdisciplinary perspectives inform understanding of a contemporary challenge or enduring question. Students will also evaluate the impact of various models of health care finance on system effectiveness.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

NURS 385.course_description: This course is an optional independent study course, in which students will participate in off-campus internships in acute or long term care settings during summer months or during the academic year to complement their formal learning experiences. They will work a minimum of 80 hours over the summer, or during a semester.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 482.course_description: FA. This seminar will explore the various graduate school options within the discipline of nursing with a specific focus on nursing research and advanced practice. It will investigate the process of graduate education from application to the acquisition of a position following graduate school. Graduate education, national priorities for nursing research, translational research, and evidence based practice will be explored in light of health care reform. The seminar will approach graduate education as means to prepare for lifelong Christian service in God’s world. This course is an elective in the Department of Nursing and will be offered once each academic year.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the nursing program; senior status is preferred.

NURS 502.course_name: Advanced Clinical Pathophysiology across the Lifespan
NURS 502.course_description: FA. The focus of this course is the application of advanced pathophysiologic concepts for frequently encountered conditions in clinical practice. It provides an in-depth analysis of epidemiology, risk factors, etiology, pathophysiology, clinical manifestations, and laboratory tests for select acute and chronic illnesses across the lifespan in the lens of the Reformed Christian worldview.

NURS 503.course_name: Advanced Clinical Pharmacology across the Lifespan

NURS 504.course_name: Clinical Health Promotion and Population Health
NURS 504.course_description: SP. This course explores theories of health promotion and disease prevention, including individual- and population-oriented preventive interventions at the advanced practice level. The course will include in-depth analyses of relevance of patient education, interprofessional teams, epidemiology, health beliefs, social determinants of health, and other factors associated with health promotion in population-based care. Students will be provided with tools to design and deliver evidence-based, culturally relevant, clinical prevention interventions among various populations across the lifespan. Competency in assessing efficiacy of a system’s capacity to serve a target sub-poplulation’s health care needs will be addressed.

NURS 505.course_name: Advanced Physical Assessment and Holistic Health Care
NURS 505.course_description: SU. In this course, students learn advanced health history and physical examination skills across the lifespan. Emphasis is on interview, communication, and psychomotor skill development, with an end goal of facilitating diagnoses of illness and disease. It also includes concepts related to health assessment, which supports the basic tenets of health promotion and disease prevention and includes concepts of holistic care.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 506.course_name: Organizational Leadership in Complex Health Systems
NURS 506.course_description: SU. This course is designed to provide students with the clincial judgment and skills necessary to work within and lead complex health care systems to promote the health needs of diverse populations. Leadership with complex systems of care will be applied in an experiential immersive experience.

NURS 507.course_description: FA. This course focuses on quality improvement processes and use of information technology within health care systems for advanced practice nursing. This assists in driving the provision of care, data collection, decision-making, communication, and knowledge expansion. In this course, students use quality improvement tools and information and technologies to drive quality-improvement strategies that benefit diverse populations across the healthcare system.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the MSN program.

NURS 508.course_name: Interprofessional Collaboration, Health Policy, and Advocacy
NURS 508.course_description: SU. The healthcare environment is ever-changing with significant health disparities associated with systemic challenges and social determinants of health. This course will focus on the importance of interprofessional collaboration in delivering holistic care to promote the health of individuals and families. The course will prepare students to effectively apply theories and models of policy-making to promote population health. Students will need to understand the context in which they are practicing and make the linkages among policy, financing, and access to quality health care. The course will include in-depth analyses of the influences of governmental policies on vulnerable populations and the complexity of financing the US healthcare delivery system to deliver safe, equitable, and ethical care. The role of the advanced practice nurse as an advocate and effective group leader or team member in health politics for the workplace, organization, government, and community will be presented.

NURS 514.course_description: SP, SU, as needed. This course requires integration of nurse educator skills into a practicum setting. The course may be taken as variable credit, but four credit hours are required (300 clock hours). The focus is on teaching and clinical practice in both a nurse academic setting and a clinical nursing education setting supervised by a preceptor expert. Logs of clock hours, practicum experiences, and teaching plans will be created and submitted to practicum instructor for feedback on a regular basis. The National League for Nursing (NLN) Nurse Educator competencies will serve as basis for practicum evaluation.  Prerequisite(s):

NURS 521.course_description: SP1. The world continues to become more interconnected, providing opportunities for both the spread of disease but also collective problem solving. This course sets the foundation for understanding how globalization affects population health across the world, introduces how we quantify the global burden of disease, identifies the global actors responsible for setting health policies and their roles, and provides a context for health and human rights. Students will identify key global health issues and needs, such as infant and maternal health, infectious diseases, and nutrition, as well as determinants of health in these areas. Crosslisted as

NURS 607.course_description: FA. This course will study the specific clinical nurse leader roles and responsibilities for providing clinical leadership for patient care practices and delivery, including the design, coordination, and evaluation of care for individuals, families, groups, and populations. The focus is to integrate patient data and apply evidenced-based strategies for managing acute and chronic illnesses for the best patient outcome. Students are expected to participate in identification and measurement of care outcomes and be accountable for evaluation and improvement of patients at the point of care. This includes risk anticipation, lateral integration of care for patients, team leadership and collaboration with other health professionals, use of information systems and technologies, and stewardship and leveraging of resources to advocate for patient.

NURS 608.course_description: SP. This course will study the specific clinical nurse leader roles and responsibilities for providing clinical leadership for patient care practices and delivery, including the design, coordination, and evaluation of care for individuals, families, groups, and populations within the mental health specialty. The focus is for students to integrate patient data and apply evidenced-based strategies for managing acute and chronic illnesses for the best patient outcomes in mental health. Students are expected to participate in identification and collection of care outcomes and be accountable for evaluation and improvement of patients at the point of care. This includes risk anticipation, lateral integration of care for patients, team leadership and collaboration with other health professionals, use of information systems and technologies, and stewardship and leveraging of resources to advocate for patient in mental health.  Prerequisite(s): NURS 607.

NURS 609.course_description: SP, SU, as needed. This course requires 300 hours of integration of clinical nurse leader skills into a practicum setting anyplace within the continuum of care within any healthcare setting. The focus is for students to integrate patient data and apply evidenced-based strategies for managing acute and chronic illnesses for the best patient outcome. Students are expected to apply theoretical knowledge gained from the Clinical Nurse Leader role course as well as MSN core courses. Students will be expected to identify role development issues, collaborative and independent practice issues, as well as problem-solving and creating best-practice methods of care.  Prerequisite(s): NURS 607.

NURS 628.course_name: Managing Community Health Issues and Systems
NURS 628.course_description: SP. This course will study the specific clinical nurse leader roles and responsibilities for providing clinical leadership for patient care practices and delivery, including the design, coordination, and evaluation of care for individuals, families, groups, and populations within the community/population health specialty. The focus is for students to integrate patient data and apply evidenced-based strategies for managing acute and chronic illnesses for the best patient outcomes in population health. Students are expected to participate in identification and collection of care outcomes and be accountable for evaluation and improvement of patients at the point of care. This includes risk anticipation, lateral integration of care for patients, team leadership and collaboration with other health professionals, use of information systems and technologies, and stewardship and leveraging of resources to advocate for patient in population health and community settings for point of care.  Prerequisite(s): NURS 607.

ENST 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

ENST 385.course_description: FA, SP, SU. This course is an internship involving field application of the concepts and principles learned as part of the environmental studies major or minor or the environmental science major. A student works as an intern under the direct supervision of an employee of a governmental agency, a not-for-profit organization, or a business, as well as under the supervision of the instructor. Interns must maintain an internship journal and complete a written report summarizing their internship experience. The credit hours vary with the number of hours worked.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 101.course_description: FA. An introduction to the engineering design process and resource design tools by means of projects, lectures, homework, mentor visits, and team meetings. Team projects, including service learning, require application of creativity, engineering analysis, and computational tools. Readings, lectures, and discussions also examine the areas of technology in society, engineering ethics, and library research methods. Various computer software tools are introduced and used.

ENGR 101L.course_description: FA. This laboratory focuses on techniques and computer software tools used for visualization and engineering communication. Graphical techniques for spatial analysis, including orthographic projection, free-hand sketching, pictorial representation, basic dimensioning, and 3-D modeling are introduced.

ENGR 202.course_description: FA, SP. A study of fundamental principles of mechanics and their application to the problems of engineering. Vector algebra, forces, moments, couples, friction, virtual work, kinematics of a particle, kinematics of a rigid body, dynamics of particles and rigid bodies, impulse, momentum, work, and energy are presented in two and three dimensions.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 204.course_description: FA, SP. An introduction to the theory and application of electronic circuits and devices. The following topics are covered: basic linear circuits (including frequency and transient response), semiconductor devices (diodes, op-amps, comparators, etc.), electric power, electric safety, and DC machines.   Corequisite(s):

ENGR 204L.course_description: FA, SP. Laboratory exercises are used to illustrate the material covered in the lecture portion of the course. Students will measure voltage, current, resistance, power, transient response, resonant circuits, voltage regulators, operational amplifiers. Students will investigate digital logic circuits.   Corequisite(s):

ENGR 205.course_description: SP. An introductory course in the science of engineering materials. Engineering properties of materials—mechanical, electrical, and chemical—are closely linked to the underlying solid state and molecular structure. Issues of stewardship and resources are addressed.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 209.course_name: Introduction to Conservation Laws and Fluid Mechanics
ENGR 209.course_description: FA, SP. This course introduces several foundational engineering topics, including engineering problem-solving techniques, process data and calculations, single- and multi-component process material and energy balances (conservation laws), and fluid statics and dynamics. Issues of stewardship of materials and resources are addressed.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 220.course_description: FA. A study of computer organization (including memory hierarchy, I/O, bus-based systems, distributed systems, and parallel systems), and computer architecture (including CPU control, pipelining, and instruction set architecture).  Prerequisite(s): a programming-language course (normally

ENGR 220L.course_description: FA. A study of computer organization (including memory hierarchy, I/O, bus-based systems, distributed systems, and parallel systems), and computer architecture (including CPU control, pipelining, and instruction set architecture). Laboratory exercises emphasize principles.  Prerequisite(s): a programming language course (normally

ENGR 250.course_description: SP. This course introduces students to the field of biomedical engineering, from the molecular and cellular level to the design and manufacturing of engineering systems used in healthcare. Topics include Biomolecular Principles, Cellular Principles, Respiration, Circulation, Biomechanics, Bioinstrumentation, Bioimaging, and Biomaterials. Content will also include discussion of biomedical engineering companies/products, government regulation, and new technologies.  Prerequisite(s): a 200-level or higher ENGR course or permission of the instructor.

ENGR 294.course_description: FA, SP. A seminar devoted to an exploration of topics in engineering. Seminars will cover areas such as the practice of engineering design, non-technical issues in engineering practice, engineering graduate studies, and aspects of engineering analysis. Students will receive transcript recognition for ENGR 294 if they attend eight (8) seminars before being admitted to a BSE concentration and will receive transcript recognition for

ENGR 295.course_description: FA. A five session workshop intended to prepare freshman/sophomore level engineering students to successfully obtain a summer internship and to be a responsible employee. The workshop topics include: Calvin’s engineering internship program, finding an internship, writing a resume, interviewing, and on-the-job behavior. Completion of the workshop is a requirement for admission to a concentration in the engineering program.

ENGR 302.course_description: SP. A study of the laws and engineering applications of electric and magnetic fields in various conductive, dielectric, and magnetic materials and under various boundary conditions. Emphasis is on the analysis and design aspects of transmission line circuits.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 303.course_description: FA. This course continues the study of chemical engineering principles begun in

ENGR 303L.course_name: Chemical Engineering Principles and Thermodynamics Lab
ENGR 303L.course_description: FA. This lab involves the study of chemical process safety as it is applied in the various process industries which include chemical, oil and gas, and pharmaceutical production, as well as experiments illustrating chemical engineering principles and thermodynamic. Topics to be covered include the following: toxicology, industrial hygiene, fire and explosion prevention, introduction to relief valves, and hazards identification assessment (HAZID). Case studies will be used to illustrate process safety analysis and improvement methods.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 304.course_description: SP. An introduction to the fundamental principles of logic design in digital systems. Topics include: Boolean algebra, analysis and synthesis of combinational and sequential networks, register transfer language, micro-operational description and applications to computer design, computer organization and assembly language programming, and asynchronous logic. The student is introduced to digital logic families and programmable logic devices, digital logic CAD tools, logic synthesis and hardware description languages (VHDL).  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 304L.course_description: SP. Laboratory work will include logic design and assembly language programming.  Prerequisite(s): Prerequisites:

ENGR 305.course_description: FA. Application of principles of mechanics to the solution of problems in stress and strain of engineering materials, including resistance to force, bending, torque, shear, eccentric load, deflection of beams, buckling of columns, compounding of simple stresses, introduction to theory of failure, and energy methods.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 306.course_description: FA. A study of environmental engineering and science principles relevant to engineered and natural systems. Topics considered in this course include an overview of the domains of environmental engineering, relevant units of measurement, population dynamics, contaminant types, sources and presence, chemical stoichiometry, equilibria, and kinetics, mass and energy balances, mass/particle transport processes, microbial ecosystem structure and function, biogeochemical cycling, and oxygen demand.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 307.course_description: FA. Advanced techniques for the analysis of analog electrical systems. Topics include: frequency domain analysis, Laplace transforms, Fourier series, Fourier transforms, and continuous versus discrete signal analysis. Frequency response is analyzed using transfer functions, Bode plots, and spectral plots. Digital Signal Processing (DSP) is introduced.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 308.course_description: SP. Application of environmental engineering and science principles to the design of environmental control measures and engineered systems. Problems considered in this course will include design of water supply and treatment processes, wastewater treatment processes, processes for air pollution control, groundwater remediation, and solid and hazardous waste management.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 311.course_description: FA. A study of the characteristics and qualitative internal action of commonly used micro-electronic devices for discrete and integrated circuits, such as diodes, metal-oxide semi-conductors FETs (MOSFETS), and bipolar junction transistors (BJTs). Application of these devices in basic amplifier circuits is explored.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 311L.course_description: FA. A study of the characteristics and qualitative internal action of commonly used micro-electronic devices for discrete and integrated circuits, such as diodes, metal-oxide semi-conductors FETs (MOSFETS), and bipolar junction transistors (BJTs). Application of these devices in basic amplifier circuits is explored. Laboratory exercises are used to illustrate concepts.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 312.course_description: SP. Thermodynamic topics important in Chemical Engineering are addressed, including the properties of real fluids and equations of state, properties of mixtures, phase equilibrium, and chemical equilibrium.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 314.course_description: SP. Analysis of mechanical vibration in both transient and steady state regimes is introduced, employing analytical and computer techniques for solution. Linear and non-linear problems are investigated with original inquiry suggested and encouraged.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 315.course_description: FA. An introduction to linear feedback control theory, including transient and frequency response, stability, systems performance, control modes, and compensation methods. Hydraulic, electrical, pneumatic, and inertial components and systems are investigated and employed. Students will not normally receive credit for both this course and

ENGR 315L.course_description: FA. An introduction to linear feedback control theory, including transient and frequency response, stability, systems performance, control modes, and compensation methods. Hydraulic, electrical, pneumatic, and inertial components and systems are investigated and employed. Laboratory exercises are used to illustrate concepts.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 318.course_description: SP, alternate years. Soils studied as engineering materials whose behavior is dependent upon soil types, index properties, and soil moisture conditions. The scope of the course includes soil structures, index properties, soil classification, permeability, compressibility and consolidation, soil testing, soil stresses, and foundation design. Laboratory experiments are used to emphasize principles.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 319.course_description: FA. An introduction to the engineering thermal sciences including elements of thermodynamics and heat transfer. Thermodynamics concepts include state properties, the first and second laws, and common cycles. Heat transfer concepts include steady state and transient conduction, forced and natural convection, radiation, and heat exchangers. Laboratory and design exercises are used to illustrate concepts.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 320.course_description: FA. Application of the basic principles of fluid mechanics to practical problems in hydraulic and hydrologic analysis. Topics include fluid statics, hydrology, open channel flow, closed conduit flow, and centrifugal pumps. Computer techniques and laboratory exercises are used to emphasize principles.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 321.course_description: SP. Application of principles of hydraulics and hydrology to the design of hydraulic systems. Problems considered in this course will include design of pipe networks for water distribution, design of sewage collection systems, design of pumping facilities, design of groundwater remediation systems, and design of flood control structures. Computer techniques will be frequently employed.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 322.course_name: Machine Design with Finite Element Analysis
ENGR 322.course_description: SP. Application of engineering mechanics, materials, and failure theories to the analysis and design of mechanical elements and systems. Computer techniques are used as aids to analysis and design.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 324.course_description: SP. This course introduces students to the various mechanical and management issues involved in the fabrication of manufactured goods. Scientific and engineering principles are applied to fabricating processes such as casting, forming, and machining so as to determine the relation of process to material properties, economics, dimensional accuracy, and energy requirements. Topics such as computer-aided manufacturing (CAM), numerical control (NC), statistical quality control (SQC), and quality management are also explored. Field trips and laboratories are used to support the lecture material.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 324L.course_name: Materials and Processes in Manufacturing Lab
ENGR 324L.course_description: SP. This course introduces students to the various mechanical and management issues involved in the fabrication of manufactured goods. Field trips and laboratories are used to support the lecture material.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 325.course_name: Computer Architecture and Digital Systems Design
ENGR 325.course_description: FA. Design of advanced digital systems using programmable logic, Application-Specific Integrated Circuits (ASICs), and microprocessors. Microprocessor architecture including pipelining, memory hierarchy, cache, instruction set architecture, CPU control, bus standards, I/O, superscalar, and Very Long Instructive Word (VLIW) approaches. Interfacing and communication techniques, including data error detection and correction codes. Introduction to parallel processing.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 325L.course_name: Computer Architecture and Digital Systems Design Lab
ENGR 325L.course_description: FA. Laboratory exercises emphasize the design of microprocessor-based digital systems.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 326.course_description: SP. A study of beams, two-dimensional trusses, and rigid frames. Course work includes calculation of shear forces and bending moments due to fixed and moving loads, calculation of deflection, analysis of moving loads using influence lines, and the analysis of statically indeterminate structures. The course also includes an introduction to matrix methods in structural analysis.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 327.course_description: FA. Application of principles of mechanics of solids and structural analysis to the design of structural members made of steel or reinforced concrete. Load and factored resistance design procedures are studied along with the current steel specification for the design, fabrication, and erection of structural steel for buildings and the building code requirements for reinforced concrete. Computer techniques are used as aids to analysis and design.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 328.course_description: SP. An intermediate treatment of heat transfer and thermodynamics including analysis and design related to steady and unsteady conduction with an emphasis on two and three dimensions, free and forced convection, radiation modes of heat transfer, power and refrigeration cycles, air conditioning processes, chemical equilibrium, and combustion. Laboratory, design, and computer exercises are utilized to emphasize principles.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 330.course_description: SP. Applications of fluid flow and heat transfer fundamentals to Chemical Engineering problems including heat exchanger design and designs for the transportation and metering of fluids. Unit operations of filtration and evaporation are covered.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 331.course_description: FA. An introduction to chemical kinetics and reactor design. Principles of kinetics of homogeneous and heterogeneous reactions with differential and integral analysis of kinetic data are included. Ideal reactor design concepts, non-isothermal reactor design, and design of catalyzed fluid-solid reactors are presented. Mass transfer, as it impacts multiphase reactor design, is introduced. One open-ended team design project and one kinetics lab project will be done to reinforce concepts presented in class.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 332.course_description: SP. Feedback principles and electronic circuit theory and device theory applied to multistage transistor amplifiers. Detailed study of operational amplifier specs, non-idealities, and compensation. Introduction to filter theory and practical realizations. Power supply design: Rectifier circuits, linear, and switching regulators. Nonlinear circuits: Comparators, multipliers, Schmitt trigger, S/H circuits, multi-vibrators, and oscillators. Introduction to noise analysis and low noise design. Emphasis on realization of designs using commercially available ICs. Design experience emphasized in projects.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 332L.course_name: Analog Circuits and Systems Design Lab
ENGR 332L.course_description: SP. Emphasis on realization of designs using commercially available ICs. Design experience emphasized in projects and the laboratory.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 333.course_description: FA. Advanced heat transfer, thermodynamic, and fluid flow topics important for the design of thermal systems are presented. Sustainability and creation care topics are covered as they pertain to energy generation and fossil fuel resource depletion. Availability (exergy) analysis and methods for the optimization of system components are discussed. Selection and design of fluid flow and heat transfer equipment used in energy conversion systems are emphasized. Economic evaluation is studied. A co-generation system is studied throughout the semester to emphasize basic principles of analysis and design. A design project focused on sustainable energy generation or energy conservation is required.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 334.course_description: SP. This course investigates various dynamic aspects of machinery. An in-depth study is made of mechanisms such as the four-bar linkage. Cams and gears are studied in the context of their use in machines. Vibration concerns are addressed including methods of balancing rotating machinery. Kinematics and kinetics are studied in a three-dimensional space with an emphasis on application in the area of robotics. Computer simulation of mechanisms is used to reinforce basic concepts.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 334L.course_name: Dynamics of Machinery and Instrumentation Lab
ENGR 334L.course_description: SP. This laboratory serves as an introduction to the characteristics and uses of transducers to measure displacement, strain, pressure, temperature, velocity, acceleration, and other physical quantities. Emphasis is on the usefulness, accuracy, and reliability of measurement systems in actual applications. Electronic signal conditioning techniques are covered. A design project using LabVIEW software and data acquisition hardware is required. Written reports required.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 335.course_description: FA. Mass transport fundamentals are applied to Chemical Engineering design problems. Principles of equilibrium mass transport operations are applied to distillation, gas absorption, extraction, and humidification design.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 337.course_description: SP. Principles of fluid flow, heat transfer, mass transfer, stage-operations, and chemical kinetics are studied using small-scale equipment. Evaluation and analysis of experimental observations, project proposals, and report writing is emphasized.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 338.course_name: Introduction to Traffic Engineering and Highway Design
ENGR 338.course_description: SP, alternate years. Introduction to the basic concepts of traffic engineering and highway design. The traffic-engineering portion introduces basic concepts including how the motorist, vehicle, road, and pedestrian interact, roadway capacity and Level-of-Service, traffic flow and queue theory, and traffic signal timing. Software applications are introduced regarding traffic simulation and capacity analysis. The highway design portion of the course focuses on the basics of horizontal and vertical alignment of roadways, design vehicle, design speed, superelevation, sight distance, and other design considerations.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Civil and Environmental Engineering concentration or permission of the instructor.

ENGR 339.course_description: FA. This is the first course in the senior design project sequence. Emphasis is placed on design team formation, project identification, and production of a feasibility study. Students focus on the development of task specifications in light of the norms for design and preliminary validation of the design by means of basic analysis and appropriate prototyping. Lectures focus on integration of the design process with a reformed Christian worldview, team building, and state-of-the-art technical aspects of design. Interdisciplinary projects are encouraged.  Prerequisite(s): admission to an engineering concentration,

ENGR 340.course_description: SP. This is the second course in the senior design project sequence. Emphasis is placed on the completion of a major design project initiated in

ENGR 342.course_description: SP. Introduction to the analysis of process dynamics, and to the design and analysis of process control systems. Covers transient and frequency response, transfer functions, stability, performance, linearization, decoupling, and multivariable control. Students will not normally receive credit for both this course and

ENGR 342L.course_name: Process Dynamics, Modeling, and Control Lab
ENGR 342L.course_description: SP. Introduction to the analysis of process dynamics, and to the design and analysis of process control systems. Covers transient and frequency response, transfer functions, stability, performance, linearization, decoupling, and multivariable control.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 350.course_description: FA, SP. This course involves study of selected special topics of current interest in engineering. Topics vary by year and may be focused on interdisciplinary problem-solving or design, advanced theoretical or experimental analysis, and/or explorations of disciplinary breadth. Consult the department website for specific sections and topics that will be offered. This course may be repeated for credit if the title and associated content differs.  Prerequisite(s): varies by course section.

ENGR 354.course_description: SP. Sustainability engineering seeks to serve the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. This course exposes students to engineering approaches to analyzing and designing engineering solutions to sustainability challenges. Topics include sustainable energy systems, sustainability analysis methods, and collective action for sustainability. The biblical basis for sustainable living is explored.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGR 385.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Engineering students who complete engineering-related internship or research work may receive transcript credit for the experience. Completion of the internship course requires a minimum of 140 hours of experiential learning, consisting of engineering professional work or academic research that emphasizes application of the knowledge and skills gained in engineering coursework. Internship projects must be guided by engineering practitioners and will be evaluated by the engineering department internship coordinator. Students must submit an internship plan, reflect on the internship experience, submit a brief written report of their activities under the signature of their supervisor, and summarize their work in a poster presentation. Questions regarding the appropriateness of specific experiential learning activities for internship credit should be directed to the engineering internship coordinator.  Prerequisite(s): completion of at least one year (>30 semester hours) of engineering program coursework.

ENGR 387.course_description: SU. Engineering students who complete engineering-related internship or research work in a country other than the United States or Canada may receive transcript credit for the experience. Completion of the international internship course requires a minimum of 140 hours of experiential learning, consisting of engineering professional work or academic research that emphasizes application of the knowledge and skills gained in engineering coursework. Internship projects must be guided by engineering practitioners and will be evaluated by the engineering department internship coordinator. Students must submit an internship plan, reflect on the internship experience, submit a brief written report of their activities under the signature of their supervisor, and summarize their work in a poster presentation. Questions regarding the appropriateness of specific experiential learning activities for international internship credit should be directed to the engineering internship coordinator.  Prerequisite(s): completion of at least one year (>30 semester hours) of engineering program coursework.

ENGR 390.course_description: FA, SP. Independent readings and research.  Prerequisite(s): permission of the chair.

ENGR 394.course_description: FA, SP. A seminar devoted to an exploration of topics in engineering. Seminars will cover areas such as the practice of engineering design, non-technical issues in engineering practice, engineering graduate studies, and aspects of engineering analysis. Students will receive transcript recognition for

FIN 201.course_description: FA, SP. Personal finance is a specialized area of study focusing on individual and household financial decisions: How much should I save? How much should I spend? How much should I give?…decisions that impact our future economic well-being. Financial planning is a process of setting financial goals and organizing assets and making decisions to achieve these goals, in an environment of risk. This class will consider financial goals for Christians and will provide information and techniques to help students be good stewards of what God entrusts to them. Topics covered will include: financial planning tools, goal setting and budgeting, tax planning, cash management, consumption and lifestyle choices, credit strategies, charitable giving, automobile and housing decisions, insurance needs, concepts of investing, estate planning and retirement planning. Class sessions will include lectures, presentations by various professionals in these disciplines, video, and group exercises and discussion.

FIN 301.course_description: FA, SP. A study of the principles and problems of the financial management of the firm, including such topics as stock and bond valuation, working capital management, financial forecasting, cost of capital and capital budgeting, capital structure, and dividend policy.  Prerequisite(s):

FIN 302.course_description: FA, SP. An application of finance theory to investment instruments, including stocks, bonds, mutual funds, options, and futures, as well as the related investment theory including risk, return, valuation, and asset allocation. The course also examines the financial markets and institutions through which these instruments trade, including investment companies, funds, exchanges, and clearing houses. The course will challenge students to critically evaluate investment principles and practices from a Christian perspective. The primary perspective taken in the course is that of a finance professional (institutional), though we will also cover select topics from the perspective of personal investment decision-making and personal finance.  Prerequisite(s):

FIN 310.course_description: SP. This course covers special topics in finance that will allow students more advanced study in specific areas of interest. Topics can include mergers and acquisitions, derivatives, capital markets, pensions, insurance, corporate valuation, credit analysis, real estate, capital budgeting, international finance, structured products, private investing, risk management, corporate social responsibility, financial planning, estate planning, retirement planning, and insurance planning and employee benefits. The topics may differ from year to year; if so, the course can be taken more than once.  Prerequisite(s):

FIN 311.course_name: Fundamentals of Financial Planning and Insurance
FIN 311.course_description: FA. Students learn the fundamentals of financial planning, including the legal, ethical, and regulatory environment. In addition, students engage the primary concepts of risk and insurance from the perspective of a financial advisory professional. The common types of risks and insurance of covered include health, life, disability, long-term care, and property and liability. Throughout, students will develop a biblical perspective of financial planning, risk, and insurance.    Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in

FIN 312.course_description: FA. Students engage the primary elements of estate planning from the perspective of a financial advisory professional. Topics include the estate planning process, the basic documents needed for an estate plan, property ownership, assets that pass through and around the probate process, gift and estate taxes, and planning techniques to reduce an individual’s tax liability. Throughout, students will develop a biblical perspective of wealth and wealth transfer.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in

FIN 313.course_description: SP. Students engage the fundamentals of retirement planning and employee benefits from the perspective of a financial advisory professional. Topics include public and private retirement plans, defined benefit and defined contribution plans, individual retirement accounts, group and fringe benefits for employers and self-employed, as well as college savings vehicles.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in

FIN 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

FIN 394.course_description: SP. This course requires students to synthesize and apply elements of comprehensive financial planning within a Christian context. The course requires students to perform all functions of the financial planning process and apply the CFP Board’s Practice Standards, including the development and delivery of a comprehensive financial plan. Additionally, this course will satisfy the educational requirements for the Certified Kingdom Advisor, CKA® designation (CKA). The course will contain two distinct elements: (1) online learning of approximately 15 modules related to the broad elements of the financial planning process; and (2) completion of a written comprehensive written financial plan for a “live” client and oral delivery of such plan. Students will utilize financial planning software in the preparation of the financial plan.  Prerequisite(s):

FIN 583.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students explore their calling and develop a deeper understanding of their chosen field. Students work an internship, keep a reflective journal, and write a reflection paper. Students must complete at least 50 hours at an internship. This course may be taken up to three times (fall, spring, summer), after admission to the MAcc program. This course is crosslisted as

FIN 601.course_description: SU1. This course covers four topics from the perspective of a corporate or nonprofit chief financial officer: mergers and acquisition, private equity, credit markets, and derivatives. Students gain an understanding of the relevant frameworks, the ability to perform financial analysis on each topic, and learn how to apply them to actual companies.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 101.course_description: FA. An introductory course in the comprehension and use of spoken and written French.

FREN 150.course_description: SU. An accelerated course in oral and written introductory French.  Prerequisite(s): 2 years of high school French; or strong organization, discipline, and high motivation.

FREN 201.course_description: FA. Further training in oral and written French, study of the structure of the language, practice in speaking, listening, reading, writing and introductory study of francophone cultures.

FREN 202.course_description: SP. Further training in spoken and written French, study of the structure of the language, practice in listening, reading, and writing, and continuing study of francophone cultures. This course provides insights into the historical, cultural, and sociological contexts which have shaped the French language.

FREN 301.course_name: Advanced French I: Sustainability in France
FREN 301.course_description: FA. In this course students will develop reading, writing, conversational, and listening comprehension skills, building vocabulary and improving grammatical precision in French. Special attention will be given to the theme of sustainability, using the French city of Grenoble as a case study.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 302.course_name: Advanced French II: Discovering the Arts
FREN 302.course_description: SP. In this course students will continue to develop reading, writing, conversational, and listening comprehension skills, building vocabulary and improving grammatical precision in French. Special attention will be given to the arts through the study of different genres (short films, song, comics, journalism, short stories, fine art) from various French-speaking countries.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 320.course_description: SU. Students will explore a French-speaking city, region, or country for two to four weeks as part of an immersion experience that will involve a homestay and intensive language study. Locations will alternate each year between France (Paris and Marseille) and Quebec (Montreal and Quebec City) or another destination.

FREN 351.course_description: FA. French culture from the Middle Ages to the present as illustrated in literature, covering selected major writers, movements, and genres. Conducted mainly in French.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 352.course_description: SP. French culture from the Middle Ages to the present as illustrated in literature, covering selected major writers, movements, and genres. Conducted mainly in French.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 361.course_description: FA. An introduction to the French-speaking culture and society of Quebec through engagement with its history, language, music, art, film, literature, politics, media, and contemporary social issues. Students discover how this francophone culture continues to thrive in North America. Conducted mainly in French.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 362.course_name: The Francophone World: West Africa and the Caribbean
FREN 362.course_description: An introduction to the culture of French-speaking Sub-Saharan Africa and the African Diaspora of the Caribbean through the writings and cinema of representative authors and filmmakers. Conducted mainly in French.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 363.course_description: An introduction to the French-speaking culture of the Maghreb (Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia) in North Africa through the writings and cinema of representative authors and filmmakers. Conducted mainly in French.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 373.course_description: An introduction to French business concepts and structures in a contemporary context. Various aspects of the French economy (transportation, trade, banks, and the European Union) as well as French business practices and language nuances in Quebec will be studied. This course develops proficiency in written and oral communication in French in a business context. Students will have the opportunity to earn the Diplôme de Français des Affaires conferred by the Chambre de Commerce et d’Industrie de Paris. Conducted mainly in French.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 375.course_description: An introduction to contemporary French cinema. Conducted mainly in French.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 381.course_description: FA, SP, as needed. Students examine a specific theme related to an aspect of French-speaking culture or cultures.  Prerequisite(s):

FREN 383.course_description: Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

GEO 101.course_description: FA, SP. This course explores human communities as they interact with the natural environment and with other communities. Attention is focused on the spatial patterns and cultural landscapes created through economic activities and as expressions of cultural values. Students learn methods of geographic research including mapping, landscape interpretation, and integrated place studies. Theoretical frameworks and models help students understand patterns of migration, settlement, land use, agriculture, industry, religion, language, ethnicity, and territorial control.

GEO 110.course_description: FA, SP. A course on the principal economic and cultural dynamics that differentiate and connect the world’s major regions from one another. Special attention will be given to the region of China.

GEO 190.course_description: FA, SP. This course gives students a broad overview of the fields of geography, geology, and environmental studies through presentations by guest lecturers, faculty members, and students as well as focused discussions about vocational choices, professional opportunities, films, and critical issues in the department’s three disciplines. Students are expected to pose questions to the specialist(s) who present.     Not offered in 2024-25.

GEO 230.course_name: The Global Economy and Transforming Regions
GEO 230.course_description: FA, alternate years. This course examines the changing geography of economic activity within the contemporary world economy. All four sectors of the economy are covered: agriculture, manufacturing, services, and information-based transactions. Theoretical concepts are grounded by way of case illustrations that focus on representative places and people in the global economy. The main geographic foci are the United States and Sudan, as well as many insightful vignettes in the series of films chosen for this course.

GEO 242.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course examines the changing geography of Africa. Course topics break up the many stereotype perspectives associated with the region. Africa is a vast and varied region, home to more than 1 billion people. Its 54 countries contain nearly 1,000 languages and ethnic groups. Thus, Africa can be understood as a land of contrasts. Students will learn from African voices in the main textbooks and from African students invited to give vignettes from their countries, followed by question-and-answer sessions. Films complement the readings, lectures, and vignettes. Students choose an African country to focus on for their final project.

GEO 250.course_description: SP. This course is a study of the atmosphere and the complex processes that control weather and climate. Students will study the components of weather and climate, including forms and movement of energy in the atmosphere; temperature patterns and relationship to energy; water in the atmosphere, clouds and precipitation; air pressure and the winds that result from its differences at Earth’s surface and aloft; and the formation of air masses and their movement as frontal systems. Building on the component knowledge, students will learn about weather systems such as thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes; weather forecasting; weather hazards; and climate change.   Corequisite(s):

GEO 250L.course_description: SP. Students experience and learn from a variety of activities that meteorologists and climate scientists do, including making direct weather observations, analyzing online data, drawing and interpreting weather maps, and examining case studies of weather events and hazards.   Corequisite(s):

GEO 260.course_description: FA, SP. This course provides an introduction to geographic information systems (GIS) and the art and science of cartography—or, as the field is increasingly termed, geographic visualization. It introduces concepts of spatial analysis (what is spatial analysis, what are methods of spatial analysis, and how does one practically conduct spatial analysis) and the elements of graphic design, particularly as applied to thematic mapping and analytical cartography with qualitative and quantitative data types. Concepts in lecture and laboratory utilize the state-of-the-art ArcGIS suite of software throughout the semester, and students will learn how to use this software for analysis and cartographic production. Also, students will learn how to communicate with a map considering the audience and the social context, various techniques of graphic design and written communication, and the map as a metaphor for reality. Finally, students learn how to “listen” to a map through a series of exercises on how to evaluate and understand maps. Crosslisted as

GEO 290.course_description: FA, SP. This course gives students a broad overview of the fields of geography, geology, and environmental studies through presentations by guest lecturers, faculty members, and students as well as focused discussions about vocational choices, professional opportunities, films, and critical issues in the department’s three disciplines. Students are expected to pose questions to the specialist(s) who present. This course meets concurrently with

GEO 295.course_description: FA, SP, as needed. This course focuses on variety of topics that are important in geography. The special topic of a particular semester is consistent with the expertise of faculty teaching the course. May be repeated with a different focus.

GEO 310.course_description: FA. A study of the growth, decline, and revitalization of cities and urban regions in North America, Europe, and the developing world. The historic and present-day spatial organization of urban transportation, land use, economic, social, and political systems are examined. We pay careful attention to the role of economic structures and transportation systems in shaping urban form and examine planning movements that aimed to create more beautiful and equitable cities.  Prerequisite(s):

GCS 300.course_description: This course is designed to help adult students explore their career interests, professional goals, and vocational trajectory. Throughout this course students will discover the skills, competencies, dispositions necessary for success in their career field. They will be invited to explore ethical frameworks that can be applied in their professional lives. Through completion of assessments, personal reflection, individual research, and interaction with the Career Center, students will become familiar with their unique strengths and the current hiring environment in their field of study to prepare themselves to be competitive for employment opportunities.

GCS 380.course_description: This course uses applied experience and academic reflection in a discipline to examine a student’s calling to meaningful work. Students work in professional settings and complete a series of assignments that connects their experience to knowledge and theories in their program of study. The course is used specifically in programs tailored for adult learners.

ACCT 203.course_description: FA, SP. The course provides an introduction to managerial accounting concepts, budgeting, incremental cost and profit analysis, breakeven analysis, responsibility reporting, and the use of financial analysis for managerial decision-making. May not be taken concurrently with

ACCT 204.course_description: FA, SP. After considering the importance of generally accepted accounting principles and the study of the accounting cycle, the course emphasizes asset valuation, classification, and measurement of liabilities, and income determination. May not be taken concurrently with

ACCT 210.course_description: SP. Small businesses are the backbone of the US economy and a primary source of jobs for Americans. This course will evaluate various accounting solutions that have been developed to assist small business. Students will evaluate current accounting theory relevant to small- to medium-size enterprises (SMEs) and apply it to practice by utilizing current software. This course may fulfill an elective in the accounting minor and, with department chair approval, the business minor.  Prerequisite(s):

ACCT 301.course_description: FA. A study of financial accounting theory and generally accepted accounting principles as applied to the measurement and valuation of assets and liabilities.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in

ACCT 302.course_description: SP. Continuation of Intermediate Accounting I. A study of financial accounting theory and generally accepted accounting principles as applied to the measurement and valuation assets, liabilities, shareholders’ equity, issues related to income determination, and preparation and analysis of corporate financial statements.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in

ACCT 305.course_description: FA, SP. A continuation of costing systems and methods. Special emphasis is given to cost concepts, classification and measurement techniques in production planning and control under job order and process.  Prerequisite(s):

ACCT 306.course_description: FA. A study of federal income tax law to provide a basis for an understanding and evaluation of that law. Examines the implications of income taxation for economic decision-making. Emphasis on taxation of individuals, with coverage of corporations, partnerships, estates, and trusts as they relate to individuals.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in

ACCT 315.course_description: SP. A study of accounting systems, which provides information for decision-making. The course examines business structures, information needed for decision-making, internal controls in manual and computerized systems, systems development, systems controls, and ethical aspects of the computer environment.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in

ACCT 320.course_description: SP. An introduction of practices and procedures of assurance services, including planning, assessing risk, testing controls, and obtaining and documenting evidence in accordance with authoritative standards including the AICPA Statements on Auditing Standards. Analyses of business processes and decisions (both financial and nonfinancial) and analytical skills needed to evaluate audit evidence, develop recommendations, and communicate findings. Emphasizes auditing from the perspective of a public accountant. Attention is also given to the roles and responsibilities of internal auditors.  Prerequisite(s):

ACCT 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

ACCT 410.course_description: SP. This course is a study of accounting for business combinations and consolidated financial statements.  Prerequisite(s):

ACCT 445.course_description: SP. This course prepares students to plan, execute, write and present descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive quantitative analyses of financial and operational data, in order to inform management decision-making. It familiarizes students with relevant software tools and techniques for preparing, analyzing, and presenting data and does so in the context of analyzing pertinent financial information. Finally, it enables students to recognize and produce high quality quantitative analyses as well as critique deceptive and manipulative abuses of quantitative analyses from a Reformed perspective.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the MAcc program.

ACCT 501.course_description: FA. This course addresses the study of business risk as viewed from the context of fraud examination. This course is designed to develop a theoretical foundation of crime causation related to fraud and white-collar crime. This course is also designed to develop forensic accounting and fraud examination skills that can be applied to prevent and detect fraud risk.  Prerequisite(s):

ACCT 508.course_description: FA. This course is an introduction to the fundamental principles of taxation related to the formation, operation, and termination of corporations and partnerships. Included are entity-related tax implications for shareholders and partners. Additional topics include multi-state taxation, international taxation, the taxation of not-for-profit entities and sales/use/value added tax.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the Master of Accounting program.

ACCT 512.course_description: FA1. This course is an examination of accounting and financial reporting for not-for-profit entities. Focus areas will include the recording, reporting, and evaluation of financial information prepared in accordance with accounting standards as promulgated by the Financial Accounting Board Standards (FASB) as applied to not-for-profit entities.  Prerequisite(s):

ACCT 514.course_description: FA2. An introduction to accounting, financial reporting, and budgeting for state and local government entities. Emphasizes accounting requirements for state and local government entities as issued by the Governmental Accounting Standards Board (GASB).   Prerequisite(s):

ACCT 521.course_description: FA. This course emphasizes the application of professional auditing standards, completing the audit process, employing advanced auditing techniques, and identifying the auditor’s role in determining whether publicly issued financial statements are fairly presented. Includes conducting audit procedures using specialized data analysis software. It builds on the knowledge base from an introductory auditing course.  Prerequisite(s):

ACCT 530.course_description: FA. Prepares students to communicate information, both within the accounting profession and to other stakeholders. Emphasizes developing a business style of writing that includes planning, critical thinking about accounting problems to be solved, organizing ideas, and producing documents or other products designed to accomplish the communicative and archival purposes pertinent to the business situation. Enables students to consider the impact of electronic communication technology on communications and writing in the accounting profession. This is a required course in the MAcc program.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the MAcc program.   Not offered in 2024-25.

ACCT 562.course_description: FA. This course examines the moral responsibilities pertinent to membership in the accounting profession, both for individual contributors and for managers of other accounting professionals and businesspeople. Emphasis is placed upon the current ethical standards of the institutions of the accounting profession, the nature of professionalism, and the particular ethical challenges and expectations that pertain to auditing, managerial accounting, and tax accounting. Philosophical and Reformed theological normative frameworks are studied, with a focus on grounding and justifying ethical standards and expectations. Written assignments and class discussion will rehearse students’ capacity for analyzing ethical issues, and for proposing solutions that will be convincing to others. Discussions and readings will explore personal and structural impediments to diversity in the workplace, and highlight best practices in inclusive leadership.  Prerequisite(s): admission to the MAcc program.

ACCT 583.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students explore their calling and develop a deeper understanding of their chosen field. Students work an internship, keep a reflective journal, and write a reflection paper. Students must complete at least 50 hours at an internship. This course may be taken up to three times (fall, spring, summer), after admission to the MAcc program. This course is crosslisted as

ACCT 590.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Independent study of topics of interest to particular students under supervision of a member of the department staff. Open to qualified students with permission of the department chair.

ART 153.course_description: FA, SP. This course focuses on how meaning is made through our visual environment. Students study a wide range of visual forms from contexts including architecture, art history, popular culture and advertising, in order to gain a better understanding of how our contemporary experiences and identities are informed and shaped by images. This course will introduce students to visual images and critically examine their various uses in contemporary culture. Class time is a combination of image analysis, image production, lectures, screenings, field trips, and student presentations. Intended for first- and second-year students.    Course fee: $50.
