BUS 357.course_description: FA. An overview of the aspects of business important to engineering. Selected topics from economics, accounting, finance, marketing, management, and business law are included.  Prerequisite(s):

BUS 390.course_description: FA, SP.   Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

BUS 391.course_description: SP, SU. Internships involve a minimum of ten hours of work a week for ten weeks (or equivalent) in a professional setting with an approved employer-supervisor in a business or nonprofit organization. Academic work includes meetings with the professor, goal setting, a final paper, an assessment from the employer-supervisor, readings, seminars/workshops, and reflective journals. For this course to fulfill a major requirement, the internship must be in the student’s major discipline.  Prerequisite(s):

BUS 392.course_description: FA, SP. Prepares students to be agents of Shalom in business organizations. Familiarizes business students with three key knowledge areas that are important for both doing business ethically and encouraging others to do likewise: current legal stipulations for business conduct, normative frameworks for evaluating actions or policies, and systems and techniques for promoting ethical behavior and overcoming rationalizations for misbehavior. Develops skills in evaluating the legal and ethical ramifications of actions or policies, and in persuasive argumentation in support of ethical actions or policies, through case studies. Hones virtues of honesty, courage, charity, creativity, empathy, humility, stewardship, compassion, justice, faith, hope, and wisdom, through reflective written exercises and case studies.  Prerequisite(s): a grade of at least a C in

BUS 393.course_description: FA, SP. An integrative study of strategic management. Students apply concepts from marketing, accounting, finance, management, and social theory to case analyses and team projects. The roles of shalom, worldviews, and ethical decision-making are emphasized.  Prerequisite(s):

BUS 394.course_description: FA, SP. This course is an experiential (project-based learning) course which is designed to have students draw upon and apply much of the knowledge and many of the skills and virtues (K, S, and V) developed in courses taken prior to the capstone in solving actual business problems for clients as members of student consulting teams. It will also require students to learn new frameworks, become familiar with industries and organizations, and to meet and to work with and for new people in compressed time frames. Students will also learn and develop a professional attitude and behaviors with which to serve clients.  Prerequisite(s):

INFO 200.course_description: FA. Student knowledge about data preparation and visualization is extended by gaining hands-on expertise with workflow software and designing dashboards and stories to explain observations of data research. Students will work through given scenarios to apply the concepts as well as providing explanations and recommendations complemented with written and oral communication. Tableau coverage will prepare the student to take the Tableau Desktop Specialist Certification.  Prerequisite(s):

INFO 301.course_description: SP. Students gain insight into common enterprise structures that support corporate information needs. After an introduction to general systems theory and the definition of an Information System, the course explores the foundational building blocks of information technology, such as networking, data repository options (relational databases, etc.), cloud resources, and data collection technology (e.g., RFID, IOT). Students will gain hands-on experience with an open-source Enterprise Resource Planning package and its subcomponents, such as Customer Relationship Management, Human Resources, and Manufacturing Requirements Planning. The course considers interorganizational systems such as EDI, blockchain, and associated standards. Students will be introduced to the implications of shalom in technology ethics, as pertaining to privacy, honesty, and consent.  Prerequisite(s):

INFO 302.course_description: FA. This course looks at implementing and applying analytics through corporate governance, systems analysis, and decision-making models. After an introduction to enterprise architectures, students will learn how to facilitate discussions and activities to analyze existing business plans, decision methodologies, and processes to reveal sources of data for knowledge mining. Each student will experience a leadership role by facilitating a case study involving business value through analytics. Students will further explore the implications of shalom in technology ethics, as pertaining to artificial intelligence, and technology as an expression of the values of its creators  Prerequisite(s):

INFO 390.course_description: SP. Student teams apply their knowledge in a data project to support a business (profit or nonprofit). The team will work through the full analytics cycle to identify a goal, gather and analyze data, visualize findings, and provide the business with either a tool or a recommendation at the end of the project. Students will regularly reflect on the application of their faith as they nurture their relationships with clients.  Prerequisite(s):

INFO 601.course_description: FA1. Collecting, managing and processing large data sets is critical to business analytics and data science. This course focuses on the core skills and concepts needed to pull data from a range of sources both inside and outside of organizations; to filter, transform, and combine data sets to prepare them for data cleaning and analysis; and construct quantitative summaries and basic visualizations.  Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program.   Not offered in 2024-25.

INFO 602.course_description: SP1. Businesses leverage increasingly large collections of data about people, products, and processes. Predictive analytics provides tools to discover patterns and anticipate trends in such data. This course introduces the foundational principles of predictive analytics and provides a survey of a wide range of predictive methods, both battle-tested classics and emerging high-capacity deep learning models.  Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program.   Not offered in 2024-25.

INFO 603.course_description: SU1. An introduction to the principles and practices of effective data visualization as an essential skill for learning from data and for communicating with others, both within and outside of an organization. Students will combine principles from statistics, psychology and computer science to design and create visualizations and use them to communicate with and about data to stakeholders and others.  Prerequisite(s): admission into the graduate business program.   Not offered in 2024-25.

CHEM 100.course_description: SP. This is a general survey course designed for the non-science major and the elementary education student. The course explores the role of chemistry and its resulting technologies in the environment and contemporary society. It emphasizes the nature of scientific investigation, some historical developments in chemical theory, chemical periodicity and reactivity, and our daily interaction with synthetic materials and chemicals. The course is taught from a biblical worldview and addresses issues such as the validity and limitations of scientific knowledge, human responsibility in applying such knowledge in society, and the care and stewardship of natural resources.

CHEM 101.course_description: FA, SP, SU. This course is a study of the basic principles of chemistry, with emphasis on the laws of chemical combination; descriptive inorganic chemistry; thermochemistry; the gas, liquid, and solid states of matter; the periodic law; atomic structure; and chemical bonding. The course is taught from a biblical and reformed worldview and addresses issues such as the validity and limitations of scientific knowledge, the methodology of the physical sciences, human responsibility in applying such knowledge in society, and the care and stewardship of natural resources.  Prerequisite(s): one year of high-school chemistry or permission of the instructor. Corequisite(s):

CHEM 101L.course_description: FA. This laboratory course focuses on learning key laboratory skills and using them knowledgeably to carry out chemical experiments that relate closely to the material of the

CHEM 102L.course_description: FA. This laboratory course focuses on learning key laboratory skills and using them knowledgeably to carry out chemical experiments that relate closely to the material of the

CHEM 103.course_description: FA. A one-semester study of the basic principles of chemistry, this course is an alternative to the

CHEM 103L.course_description: FA. This laboratory course focuses on learning key laboratory skills and using them knowledgeably to carry out chemical experiments that relate closely to the material of the

CHEM 121.course_description: SP, alternate years. Culinary medicine is an evidence-based field that combines nutrition and culinary knowledge in maintaining health and preventative care. This course will examine several common diets and the associated health benefits, and focus on the whole food, plant-based diet that is an ideal diet for both human and planetary health. Students will learn about dietary behavior changes and food chemistry as well as practice cooking skills that lead to a healthier diet. Through this course, students will see how food and cooking can be incorporated into healthcare and community goals.    Lab fee: $195.

CHEM 140.course_description: FA. This survey course is specifically for the preparation of high school (7-12) science teachers as well as those who opt to specialize in chemistry education. The fundamental concepts of organic chemistry and biochemistry are presented with an emphasis on the chemical nature of biological systems. Topics such as structure, functional groups, and chemical reactivity are illustrated using common organic molecules, including enzymes, buffers, and cellular energy metabolism.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 160.course_description: FA. This survey course is specifically designed for those planning for a health care major, including nursing or other allied health science careers that require a chemistry course. The fundamental concepts of general chemistry, organic chemistry, and biochemistry are presented with an emphasis on the chemical nature of biological systems. Topics such as molecular bonding and structure, equilibrium chemistry, and chemical reactivity are illustrated by acid/base reactions and redox reactions, presented in a biological context such as membranes, enzymes, buffers, and cellular energy metabolism. Issues regarding the ethics and stewardship of health will also be discussed.  Prerequisite(s): high school chemistry. Corequisite(s):

CHEM 160L.course_name: Chemistry for the Health Sciences Lab
CHEM 160L.course_description: FA. This laboratory course focuses on observing key concepts and basic laboratory skills that relate closely to the material of the

CHEM 171.course_name: Chemistry, Policy, and the Future of Our Planet
CHEM 171.course_description: SP. Students interested in public health, public policy, or advocacy work should know the science behind chemical advances and natural phenomena so that they can make decisions that promote the sustainable flourishing of the planet. This course will provide students with chemical principles related to direct application of chemistry to the environment (pesticides, herbicides, fertilizers) as well as additional applications including drinking water, climate change, energy sources (combustion, solar, nuclear), batteries, and consumer products. Students will learn about past, current, and possible government policies (federal, state, local) that can be used to regulate and incentivize chemistry for flourishing.    Lab fee: $195.

CHEM 172.course_description: FA, alternate years. There are many ways to understand water: it is a substance that can be studied chemically, it is a resource that can be studied politically and economically, and it is a symbol that can be studied philosophically. Students will learn about the chemical nature of water and how its molecular structure determines its ability to host so many important chemical reactions and processes. Throughout the course, students will also learn about the availability and right to water for all humans as they rely on water for survival, enjoyment, and significance.

CHEM 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

HNRS 234.course_description: FA, SP, as needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will investigate a variety of contemporary topics and challenges within the field of chemistry through an interdisciplinary lens. Students will learn foundational chemistry concepts, develop an appreciation for the investigatory process of science as a value-laden collaborative enterprise, explore the reliability of scientific knowledge, and consider social and ethical aspects of scientific methodologies and findings.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 210.course_description: FA, SP. Features a problem-solving approach that incorporates sampling, sample preparation, separation of analytes from interfering substances, measurement and data analysis interpretation. Quantitative analysis is presented in the context of analytical methods that include statistics of sample measurements (significance tests, outlier tests, linear regression), separation science (gas, liquid, and chromatography), optical spectroscopy (UV-visible, fluorescence, and atomic absorption spectroscopy), and electrochemistry (electrode potentials, and ion-selective electrodes). Highly recommended for 1st- and 2nd-year students, and not open to seniors except by permission.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 210L.course_description: FA, SP. Experiments applying analytical chemistry to art, nanotechnology, spectroscopy, gas- and liquid-based separations, and forensic science will be performed. Relevant statistical methods to data analysis will be performed.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 230.course_description: SP. This foundational course for 1st- and 2nd-year students covers the properties and trends of molecules derived from across the periodic table, with emphasis on the main group elements. Topics covered include periodicity, bonding, symmetry, and reactivity. Special attention will be given to visualization tools for molecular structures. Upon completion of the course, students will be prepared to critically compare and contrast molecular and biomolecular structures with chemical reactions presented in subsequent course work throughout the science division.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 230L.course_description: SP. Fundamental analytical and synthetic techniques associated with an inorganic chemistry laboratory will be learned. This includes the ability to safely run aqueous inorganic reactions and characterize products using a wide array of techniques (UV-Visible Absorbance, Magnetometry, Cyclic voltammetry, and Computational Chemistry). A lab notebook will be maintained, and completed experiments will be summarized in written lab reports.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 240.course_description: FA. A study of organic compounds, reactions, and reaction mechanisms, emphasizing their biochemical significance.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 240L.course_description: FA. Fundamental analytical and synthetic techniques associated with an organic chemistry laboratory will be learned. This includes the ability to safely run organic reactions, work up and purify synthesized products, and characterize them with data obtained via modern instrumentation such as IR and NMR spectrometers. A lab notebook will be maintained, and completed experiments will be summarized in written lab reports.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 241.course_description: FA. A detailed study of organic compounds, their synthesis, and reactions, presented within the framework of modern physicochemical theory, together with an introduction to modern methods of analysis and identification. Majors and minors enrolling in this course must also take

CHEM 241L.course_description: FA. Introductory synthetic techniques associated with an organic chemistry laboratory will be learned. This includes the ability to safely run organic reactions and to work up and purify synthesized products. Introductory use of modern instrumentation such as IR and NMR spectrometers will complement benchtop techniques. A lab notebook will be maintained, and completed experiments will be summarized in written lab reports.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 351.course_description: FA. A study of macroscopic properties of matter as described by chemical thermodynamics and kinetics. Major topics include the laws of thermodynamics and their application to pure substances, chemical reactions, solutions, physical and chemical equilibria, and reaction kinetics.  Prerequisite(s):

CHEM 351L.course_description: FA. Laboratory offering experience with fundamental thermodynamic properties (internal energy, enthalpy, entropy), measurement of fundamental physical properties, determination of molar mass, properties of mixtures and chemical kinetics, along with techniques for analysis of experimental data.   Corequisite(s):

BCHM 321.course_description: FA, SP. How does chemistry help us understand biological systems? This course is an introduction to the principles of biochemistry in which we focus on the structure and function of proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, and nucleic acids. The fundamentals of signaling and metabolism and their associated mechanisms of regulation will also be introduced.  Prerequisite(s):

BCHM 321L.course_description: FA, SP. This lab will introduce modern biochemical separation and analytical techniques. Students will collect and analyze experimental data related to protein expression, purification, and characterization. A particular emphasis will be placed on learning to clearly explain biochemical results and their applications in a research setting.   Corequisite(s):

BCHM 322.course_description: SP. Metabolism is the set of chemical reactions that occur in living organisms to produce energy and the molecules that are necessary to sustain life. This course will explore cellular metabolism with a focus on the relationships between key metabolic pathways and human diseases. The primary goal of this course is to explore the ways in which chemical principles play fundamental roles in biological systems and how changes to these systems contribute to disease phenotypes.  Prerequisite(s):

BCHM 322L.course_description: SP. In this literature lab, students will broaden their exposure to metabolism and metabolic diseases through weekly presentations and discussions of research data and primary literature. Students will learn how to engage effectively with the primary literature in the field of biochemistry.   Corequisite(s):

BCHM 323.course_description: SP. Living cells and organisms must respond to their environment, which allows them to adapt to a variety of external conditions. We will use the language of chemistry (thermodynamics, kinetics, analysis, reactivity, and modeling) to explore systems of interactions and regulations within and between cells. Students will learn how signaling and regulation within complex biological systems leads to biological function, behavior, homeostasis, adaptation, and the emergence of new traits. We will then use these tools to examine the biochemistry of how animals, insects, plants, and microbes employ toxins to disrupt signaling pathways as a means of defense or attack.  Prerequisite(s):

BCHM 323L.course_description: SP. This lab will expand students’ understanding of protein interactions and how they relate cellular responses to toxins such as venom. Students will engage with common biochemical techniques used to study signaling pathways and learn approaches to study the disruption of those pathways in model organisms.   Corequisite(s):

BCHM 324.course_description: SP. Proteins play a multitude of roles in cell structure and function. To understand these roles, this class will go deeper into how the unique three-dimensional structures of proteins arise and influence their roles in catalysis, regulation, recognition, and information storage. Special attention will be paid to protein mutations. Students will develop an enhanced structural, thermodynamic, and dynamic understanding of biomacromolecules and their biological functions. Students will also explore how alternations in structure confer new biological properties on proteins.  Prerequisite(s):

BCHM 324L.course_description: SP. This lab will explore how changing environmental conditions impact a variety of protein structures and functions. The impact of environmental changes will be assessed by measuring properties such as protein folding or enzyme kinetics. Computational modeling will also be used to better visualize macromolecules and key elements of their stability and regulation.   Corequisite(s):

ENGL 315.course_name: Advanced Studies in Later British Literature
ENGL 315.course_description: A focused study of British literatures from the Restoration to the present. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a specific time period within this broader range.

ENGL 320.course_description: A focused study of American literature. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a specific time period within this broader range.

ENGL 325.course_name: Advanced Studies in Children's and Adolescent Literature
ENGL 325.course_description: A focused study of children’s and adolescent literature. The course may be thematic or genre-focused, or it may concentrate on a time period or specific region.

ENGL 330.course_description: A focused, advanced study of a medium or literary genre. The course may focus on the characteristics of a single genre, such as poetry, novel, plays, etc, or of multiple genres.

ENGL 335.course_name: Advanced Studies in a Major Author
ENGL 335.course_description: A focused study of a major literary figure.

ENGL 340.course_description: A course in rhetoric and composition designed for students who wish to prepare for writing in their professions or in graduate school. Students enhance their abilities to create and edit effective writing in the genres that they will encounter as professionals.

ENGL 341.course_description: SP. A course in the art of writing feature stories for digital publications, newspapers, and magazines. Students research, write, and edit several substantial articles for different audiences, paying particular attention to matters of strategy and style as called for by those audiences. Topics range from profiles of people to articles about science, history, religion, art, or politics. Although the primary focus of the course is writing, students do explore the possibilities of multimedia journalism.

ENGL 342.course_description: A course that engages students in writing rhetorically effective digital texts. Students will apply rhetorical, aesthetic, and technical principles as they write extensively in a variety of genres such as social platforms, chat apps, short-form video, and niche newsletters. Special attention will be paid to questions of authorship and copyright when writing in digital environments.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGL 344.course_name: Special Topics in Advanced Professional Writing
ENGL 344.course_description: A focused study of professional writing in a particular subgenre or topic area.

ENGL 350.course_description: FA. A course in the theory and practice of teaching composition in middle and high school writing and language arts programs. Extensive reading complements frequent writing about and practice in all elements involved in teaching writing. Majors and minors in English secondary education programs must take this course before enrolling in

ENGL 360.course_description: FA. A course in the principles and practice of creative nonfiction. Students will examine a variety of models and engage in extensive practice of the genre. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGL 361.course_description: A course in the principles and composition of poetry. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer.  Prerequisite(s): Prerequisite:

ENGL 362.course_description: FA, SP. A course in the principles and composition of fiction. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer.

ENGL 364.course_description: A focused study of creative writing in a particular subgenre or topic area.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGL 367.course_description: FA, SP. An intensive writing course, typically led by Calvin’s writer-in-residence. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer. Students can repeat the course up to four times.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGL 368.course_name: Writing for Children and Young Adults
ENGL 368.course_description: A course in the principles and composition of writing for children and young adults. Students will engage in extensive practice. Special emphasis will be given to the relationship between faith and art for the writer.  Prerequisite(s):

ENGL 371.course_description: SP. An analysis of the changes that have occurred throughout the history of the English language, based on an intensive study of selected British and American texts.

ENGL 372.course_name: Sociolinguistics and Issues in Language Education
ENGL 372.course_description: FA. A course involving two major activities: (1) an examination of selected topics that have arisen in recent sociolinguistic research, particularly those topics centering on questions about how standard and nonstandard languages and dialects appear to affect people’s educational success; and (2) an evaluation of how these topics should affect approaches to language education, particularly approaches to teaching English as a Second Language (ESL).  Prerequisite(s):

ENGL 373.course_description: SP. A course that reviews significant grammatical terms; analyzes how words can be combined into longer constructions in English; examines the kinds of meanings–such as agency, modality, and solidarity–that those constructions can convey; and discusses how patterns of clauses conveying these various kinds of meaning within texts can be related to textual contexts.

ENGL 376.course_description: FA, SP, as needed. A focused study of linguistics in a particular field or topic.

ENGL 380.course_description: FA, SP. A course requiring students to work ten hours per week in a job related to English studies. This practicum asks students to reflect on vocation broadly and to apply theoretical, technical, and ethical principles to their work. Students will work with the Career Center to secure a suitable position.  Prerequisite(s): junior or senior status, a 2.0 university and departmental GPA, and permission of the advisor.

ENGL 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

ENGL 390.course_description: FA, SP.   Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

ENGL 395.course_description: FA, SP. A capstone course for all English majors. This senior seminar is designed to nurture Christian reflection on issues related to writing, language, and literary studies, such as the significance of story and literary expression, the relationship of language and meaning, and the ethical implications of language and story. Students also consider vocational opportunities for those who love words. These contemporary literary and linguistic issues are framed by readings from within the tradition of Christian aesthetic reflection as well as from reformed cultural criticism and theology. Significant written work is required.  Prerequisite(s):

HNRS 211.course_description: FA, SP, as needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will emphasize creative writing (whether nonfiction, fiction, or poetry) as a form of problem-solving, embedded within larger social contexts. Particular attention will be paid to genre conventions and audience expectations. The interdisciplinary component will attend to how writing not only expresses ideas but gives shape to them along the way.  Prerequisite(s):

HNRS 222.course_description: FA, SP, as needed. Designed to be paired with another 2-semester-hour HNRS course, this course will engage questions about the meaning of human life and experience in dialogue with literary texts and traditions. While readings will vary from year to year, in all iterations students will hone skills of close textual analysis, cultural and ideological discernment, and expository writing. Genre conventions and social context will be primary concerns.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 103.course_description: FA, SP. This course invites students to explore the discipline of education and the teaching profession. Students will experience various types of schools and other educational settings through visits, interviews, and virtual connections with elementary and secondary students and staff locally and around the world. Students will reflect on these experiences in writing, group discussions, chats, video, and other platforms. The course provides the initial framework for subsequent education courses and clinical experiences, introducing students to primary issues and components of schools as well as engaging them in Christian practices for teaching in various settings.

EDUC 115.course_description: FA, SP. This initial course in the three-course literacy sequence focuses on understanding current research underlying key concepts such as phonics, phonological awareness, concepts of print, and reading fluency. These basic concepts are learned within the overarching context of all literacy instruction being focused on thinking, understanding and engagement. Teacher candidates deepen their understanding of these concepts through a 20-hour practicum with primary grade students in a linguistically diverse school.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 210.course_name: Music and Art in the Elementary Classroom
EDUC 210.course_description: FA, SP. This is a required course for the elementary teacher candidate. It covers seven weeks of music education methods and seven weeks of visual arts methods. Integration of music and art with other subject areas will be stressed. Students will explore the creative process through vocal and instrumental music, visual arts production, and lesson planning.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 215.course_description: FA, SP. Candidates learn how to design and enact a range of instructional strategies and routines to support students in becoming skillful and engaged readers across subject areas. Candidates also learn the principles and strategies for effective vocabulary instruction and how to assess writing. This course includes a 20-hour practicum where candidates create lessons and assessments for the teaching of reading comprehension and writing.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 236.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course addresses theories of child development and applications within the natural or preschool learning environments. Students will explore foundations of early childhood education practices, including observational research techniques, classroom or natural environment observation of children from birth through kindergarten, and writing developmental assessment reports. Twenty hours of field experience outside of the classroom are required.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 238.course_name: Developmentally Appropriate Practice with Young Children
EDUC 238.course_description: FA. Work with young children requires specialized knowledge of the field of early childhood education. This course will equip students with knowledge and skills for developmentally appropriate practice for young children, including culturally responsive perspectives and pedagogical strategies addressing the importance of play in learning, social-emotional development, early literacy, and early mathematics. Ten hours of observation in a preschool setting will be required.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 240.course_description: FA, SP. This course guides students in an examination of the social context of schooling, including the interaction and impact of social structures and systems on the educational experiences of individuals and groups. Particular attention is given to the study of race, class, and gender and how social science helps us understand their impact on schools, society, and learners. A biblically-guided understanding of justice helps shape this critical analysis. This course includes a 12-hour project involving field work and centered on schools, communities, and families.

EDUC 241.course_name: Inclusive Teaching: Ability, Language, and Multicultural Education
EDUC 241.course_description: FA, SP. This course provides insight into learners with diverse ability and linguistic background. It includes study of the role of culture in language development and academic achievement; second language development theories for classroom organization and pedagogy; characteristics of students with identified disability; and the history of special education, individualized planning, and pedagogy. A Christian view of persons is developed to counteract deficit thinking, recognize the gifts of all students, and identify human and linguistic difference as asset. Twelve hours will be spent outside of class in observation of K-12 school programs.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 243.course_description: FA, SP. Students will actively explore the core knowledge, practices and dispositions of teaching and learning through examination of model teaching, enactment of practice teaching in small groups, and reflective discussion. The course will focus on what it means to live out Christian faith commitments and practices in a variety of settings. This includes consideration of who teaches and is taught, what is taught, how and in what context we teach, and the complex ways in which these ideas interact and compete in PK-12 classrooms.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 249.course_description: FA, SP. This course will examine multiple frameworks for understanding how Christian commitments can inform teacher identity and formation and guide professional practice. The course will include attention to how the Bible, with its diversity of genres, functions as an educational text, as well as to exemplars of Christian engagement with education and key facets of teacher and student vocation. A range of faith-informed practices will be examined as they apply to professional practice in educational settings.  Prerequisite(s): a Foundations of Christianity I Core course.

EDUC 250.course_description: FA, SP. Students consider how to teach the social studies through inquiry, with a special emphasis on children Pre-K through grade 6. Knowledge development will focus primarily on the geographic, sociocultural, global, and political threads of the social studies. The inquiry process will be modeled with an exploration of a global region. Participants will develop their skills in core teaching practices.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 307.course_name: Curriculum, Instruction, and Content Area Literacy
EDUC 307.course_description: FA, SP. Students will develop an increased understanding of the complex issues surrounding learning theory and its impact on instruction in diverse educational contexts. Students will explore how an understanding of the learner, the curriculum, and the context shape instructional practice. They will learn how to engage in a pedagogical cycle that includes planning, implementation, evaluation, and reflection with a focus on meeting the needs of all learners. Students will also examine the nature and function of literacy in the secondary content curriculum. Specifically, this course will examine the reading and writing skills and practices that support the ways of knowing and doing characteristic of secondary school subject areas. All of these areas will be examined through the lens of a reformed Christian perspective. An extensive practicum will assist students in linking theory and practice in a classroom setting.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 308.course_description: FA, SP. This internship provides field-based learning through a part-time placement in a grade 5-12 classroom. With the supervision of a faculty member and a master teacher, interns develop their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills and dispositions expected of 5th- to 12th-grade educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aide interns in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field. A grade of C or higher along with the recommendation of the course instructor are required to continue in the education program.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 309.course_name: Teaching Religion to Children and Adolescents
EDUC 309.course_description: FA. A study of perspectives, content, methods, and materials in teaching religion to children and adolescents. This includes pedagogy appropriate for public and non-public schools and evaluation of methods and materials.

EDUC 310.course_name: Assessment in Early Childhood and Special Education
EDUC 310.course_description: FA, SP. A study of the foundational concepts and basic terminology needed for administering developmentally appropriate assessment. Skill will be developed in thoughtfully creating, selecting, administering, and interpreting formal and informal assessments. Norm-referenced, criterion-referenced, curriculum-based, and play-based assessment will be addressed for the purpose of developing Individualized Education Programs (IEPs), Individualized Family Service Programs (IFSPs), and Section 504 plans.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 315.course_name: Extending and Deepening Literacy Instruction: Internship I
EDUC 315.course_description: FA, SP. Candidates learn how to teach engaging literacy lessons and design instructional strategies that support students in becoming skillful and engaged readers and writers across subject areas. Candidates further develop their understanding of creating equitable classroom cultures; their capacity to design literacy programs that reflect their knowledge of curriculum, assessment, and instruction; and their knowledge, skill, and commitment to equitable and justice-oriented practices.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 330.course_description: SP. A study of the various curricula, instructional materials, and teaching methods appropriate for learners who have cognitive impairment. Research-based general principles of instruction are reviewed as well as specific methods for teaching daily living, communication, employment, community living, recreation/leisure, faith formation, and functional academic skills. Strategies are learned for generating curriculum, evaluating published curricula, and developing individualized education programs. Includes a practicum of two half-days per week in local school programs serving students with cognitive impairment.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 331.course_name: Introduction to Cognitive Impairment: Birth through School Age
EDUC 331.course_description: SP. A comprehensive study of the characteristics of infants and children who have cognitive impairment, intellectual or developmental disability, or developmental delay. Common causes, medical and school-based definitional issues, assessment, eligibility for special education, and interventions will be discussed. While special attention is given to supports for children with cognitive impairment as learners, the course examines functioning across a variety of settings besides the school, such as the church, home, and neighborhood. A Christian view of persons, community, and discipleship, along with the concepts of inclusion, social role valorization, and self-determination are integrating elements in the course. Seven hours of observation in a local school or early childhood program is required for this course.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 332.course_name: Introduction to Cognitive Impairment: Transition to Adulthood
EDUC 332.course_description: SP. A comprehensive study of the characteristics of persons who have intellectual disability. Historical and contemporary perspectives on intellectual disability will be explored, as will common causes, definitional issues, and interventions. The course examines the transition to adulthood in a variety of settings besides the school, such as the church, workplace, and neighborhood. A Christian view of persons, community, and discipleship, along with the concepts of normalization, social role valorization, and self-determination are integrating elements in the course. Seven hours of observation in a transition or adult services program is required for this course.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 337.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course provides an exploration of the major approaches to development of a curriculum for infants, toddlers, and preschool-age children (birth to age six), the underlying assumptions of each approach, and the appropriateness of each approach for children. Special attention is given to supporting the development of early literacy and numeracy. This course includes a 6-hour per week field placement during the PK-12 school day.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 339.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course examines the knowledge and skills required to become a collaborative educator who identifies as a Christian early childhood professional, can administer programs, understands and works alongside children and families from diverse backgrounds, can recognize and report child abuse and neglect, is a strong advocate for children and families, and is a reflective practitioner committed to life-long learning.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 343.course_name: Early Childhood Education: Preschool Field Experience
EDUC 343.course_description: FA. A field experience in a preschool setting that meets state requirements. Provides for analysis of teaching methods, materials, and classroom organization as they relate to the early childhood setting.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 346.course_description: FA, SP. This internship provides field-based learning through a full-time placement in a grade K-12 classroom. With the supervision of faculty members and master teachers, candidates refine their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills and dispositions expected of educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aid candidates in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field.  Prerequisite(s): an overall GPA of 2.5, Internship I (

EDUC 347.course_description: SP. Full-time, supervised student teaching in a school program serving students with cognitive impairment. A minimum of ten weeks, including at least 360 clock hours of observation and participation, is required. Includes a biweekly seminar, which engages students in critical reflection on their experience in applying theory to practice in the student teaching context.  Prerequisite(s): Completion of all special education major courses and the recommendation of the

EDUC 350.course_name: Teaching Social Studies in Elementary Grades: Internship I
EDUC 350.course_description: FA, SP. Students consider social studies content and pedagogy for children from Pre-K through grade 6. Knowledge development will focus primarily on the political and economic threads of the social studies. The inquiry process and other social studies instructional strategies will be developed with an emphasis on finding quality sources (including children’s and adolescent literature) for children’s exploration of social studies content and issues in the social studies. Through classroom peer teaching and a practicum, participants further develop and demonstrate core teaching practices in their practicum settings.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 359.course_description: FA, SP. Taking an interdisciplinary perspective, students will consider the question, “What contributes to flourishing in learning communities?,” particularly when faced with a contemporary challenge. Pulling from experiences in their full-time internship in a P-12 classroom, previous program coursework, research, and personal inquiries, students will select a challenge that transpires in their assigned placement. They will consider how self, context and the core aspects of teaching (pedagogy, curriculum, assessment, and classroom management) along with a Reformed Christian worldview inform their response and engage practice in ways that foster greater flourishing for all.  Prerequisite(s): an overall GPA of 2.5, Internship I (

EDUC 380.course_description: FA, SP. Students work in a position related to schooling and/or the support of individuals who have identified disabilities. Taken as part of an education major or special education studies minor, the internship will provide students an opportunity to consolidate their study of teaching, learning, and support for children and families. Students will work with the School of Education faculty and/or the Career Center to secure a suitable position.  Prerequisite(s): a 2.0 university and departmental GPA, and permission of the advisor and of the on-site advisor.

EDUC 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): Not open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

EDUC 390.course_description: FA, SP.   Prerequisite(s): permission of the department chair.

EDUC 399.course_description: FA, SP. Students examine education in its context as a life practice. It involves inquiry into and critique of the philosophical assumptions, historical developments, and social settings that shape the beliefs and practices informing schools as social institutions and education as a cultural practice. Throughout the course, students are developing their own faith-based philosophy of education.  Prerequisite(s): junior or senior standing,

EDUC 507.course_name: Curriculum, Instruction, and Content Area Literacy
EDUC 507.course_description: FA. Students will examine the nature and function of literacy in the secondary content curriculum. Specifically, this course will examine the reading and writing skills and practices that support the ways of knowing and doing characteristic of secondary school subject areas. All of these areas will be examined through the lens of a reformed Christian perspective. An extensive practicum (

EDUC 508.course_description: FA. This internship provides field-based learning through a part-time placement in a grade 6-12 classroom. With the supervision of a faculty member and a master teacher, interns develop their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills, and dispositions expected of 6th- to 12th-grade educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aide interns in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field. Students will complete a project tailored to their disciplinary interests.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 510.course_name: Framing Questions, Global Forces, Constraining Structures
EDUC 510.course_description: FA. This course will center on fundamental questions at the intersection of education, justice, and human flourishing. We will examine key issues surrounding the nature of a good society, the ways in which the global community affects education, and how schooling gets structured by politics and economics. This course will use the faith-based frames of justice and hope in connection with shalom and the kingdom of God to investigate formal education in light of its political, economic, social, and religious contexts. Students will investigate foundational questions around teaching, learning, curriculum, and language as well as structural issues of social class, gender, ability, and race. The aim is for students to articulate their own idea of the purpose of school framed in their own faith-based perspective. The course will leave space for students to explore specific interests and issues.

EDUC 514.course_description: SU. This course engages students in understanding and examining the theories, methods, and paradigmatic frames of educational research through a biblical lens. In addition, the course prepares students to use data appropriately to support educational and organizational decision-making. Students will learn how to read and critique qualitative and quantitative educational research and will learn how to use research and assessment data to make decisions related to the work of P-12 schools.

EDUC 516.course_description: SP. Because communication is at the heart of teaching, learning and leading, the Graduate Studies Program prepares professional educators to understand and analyze discourse as it shapes educational activity. Teaching and learning communications are shaped and made meaningful by culture, language, mode and circumstance; as well as ideology and power. Abilities to analyze communication as discursive, prepares participants to examine educational activity settings, assess them for equitable participation and design them for more effective and just educational practice.

EDUC 522.course_description: SP. The dynamic relationship between curriculum as content and as process, between what is to be learned and the instructional practices used to organize and mediate it for students, is at the heart of educational practice. This course focuses on the theory and practice of curriculum and pedagogy, examined in terms of both the perspectives that shape them and the ways in which they serve or fail to serve all learners. Issues addressed include the concept, purpose, and social context of curriculum; the historical perspectives that influence current and future directions; the relationship between curriculum and instruction; and the connection between perspectival commitments, curriculum, and instruction. The course will also address issues and practices related to assessment and instructional technology. Readings, discussions, interaction with practitioners, investigation, and application will form important activities in the development of an understanding of and personal perspective on curriculum and instruction.

EDUC 530.course_description: SU, alternate years. A study of leadership theory and practice relating to building school communities that promote learning for all students. This introductory course in school leadership will focus on: organizational and leadership theory, establishing a school mission, collaborative problem-solving and community building, decision-making skills and procedures, and personal leadership qualities. Special emphasis will be given to exploring biblical principles which guide Christian leaders in school settings.

EDUC 531.course_description: SU, alternate years. A study of the theory and practice related to the professional development of teachers and administrators at both the elementary and secondary levels. This course focuses on ways in which school leaders can structure professional development opportunities that promote student learning and school improvement. The course includes a study of adult learning theory, collaborative learning models, mentoring and coaching, formal and informal teacher assessment, and recruitment, induction, and retention of new teachers. Special emphasis will be given to biblical principles which help shape professional communities in schools.

EDUC 532.course_description: FA, alternate years. In this course students will study principles and methods of planning and fiscal management that are based on a biblical model of stewardship. Topics include the process of funding (fund raising, tuition and fees), budgeting (including risk management), and organization.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 542.course_description: FA. This course meets the state literacy course requirements for professional certification. It is required as part of the Calvin graduate reading specialist endorsement and can be used as an elective in any of the other Calvin MEd programs. In this course, we consider the developmental, socio-cultural and cognitive aspects of literacy teaching with students of all ages. We review literacy practices including fiction, information and discipline specific texts, special interest reading, and work place literacy. The course presents and critiques current positions from which literacy instruction is designed and delivered. It develops participants’ pedagogy as they learn to assess a reader’s abilities and develop instructional responses. Participants enhance their own critical literacy abilities as readers and writers of text. Course participants undertake a case study to complement the course readings, discussion and other learning. Course objectives are met through a deep engagement with a student who has been identified as an “at risk” reader based on classroom performance, ELL status or special education. This authentic engagement, facilitated by professional observations, assessments, and a responsive intervention, fully complements and activates course objectives.

EDUC 544.course_name: The Early Literacy Learner, At Home and in School
EDUC 544.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course examines the social practices and cognitive development by which children progress towards independent abilities to participate in reading activity. Course participants identify young learner’s diverse social-cultural memberships, language abilities and the environmentally influenced experiences that children bring to school. Participants explore the concepts and abilities necessary to the development of new literacy learners. Using research, theory and experience, participants explore, analyze, and practice classroom pedagogies that best nourish each literacy learner’s foundation towards independent abilities for reading and writing.

EDUC 545.course_name: Literacy Learning after the Early Years: Middle School Children, Adolescents and Adults
EDUC 545.course_description: FA, alternate years. This course supports educator’s literacy development of middle school students, adolescents and adult literacy learners. Instructional emphases shift from the earlier years. Older literacy learners engage wide-ranging text forms and specialized vocabulary needs. Their school learning and work lives depend on abilities to interact purposefully and knowledgeably with print, digital or electronic texts. Increasingly self-directed, older learners need reading abilities to select apt comprehension strategies; respond critically to a reading; determine the applications of a text to other experience or situations; as well as determine objectives in their production of texts. Course participants: classroom teachers, coaches, resource room educators, community programmers, and adult literacy instructors, develop their professional knowledge and pedagogies to assist viewers and readers become more critical and discriminating readers and producers of texts.

EDUC 546.course_description: SP. This internship provides field-based learning through a full-time placement in a grade K-12 classroom. With the supervision of faculty members and master teachers, candidates refine their understanding and performance of the knowledge, skills, and dispositions expected of educators. Individual observations, mentoring, and coursework aid candidates in developing as professionals. Varied frameworks and tools are used throughout the internship to assess readiness for the professional field. Students will complete a project tailored to their disciplinary pedagogy interests.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 554.course_name: Pathways to Inclusion: Re-examining Beliefs about Learners
EDUC 554.course_description: SP. Schools and classrooms today reflect an amazing diversity of learners. In any learning community, educators must be prepared to create a learning community that meets the needs of students with a variety of differences in ability, gender, sexuality, race/ethnicity, language, socioeconomic status, and more. Yet the reality of developing just and inclusive educational communities is challenging. Through this course, participants are invited to embark on pathways to inclusion by examining the needs of learners with differences in school contexts. Participants will re-examine commonly held beliefs and practices about identity and difference with the goal of developing inclusive learning communities. Readings and discussions will create opportunities that allow participants to consider how cognitive, socio-cultural, and critical perspectives are tools for thinking about shifting understandings of learners’ differences. Learning excursions and projects will become spaces for integrating and applying new understandings about ourselves and others within teaching/learning practice. The course will specifically focus on linguistic differences, language development, and literacy as they support or impede the inclusion of all learners in educational contexts.

EDUC 555.course_description: FA, alternate years. This course will explore critical strategies for successful inclusive teaching practices that support all learners. Educators will refine their understanding of culturally responsive educational design as they research accessible curricular programs and evidence-based practices for successful learning. Emphasis will be placed on locating and evaluating the quality of instructional programs or practices, planning with Universal Design for Learning, and exploring faith-based perspectives to promote inclusion. An ongoing curricular design project will allow educators to develop units or professional learning opportunities informed by inclusive programs and practices.

EDUC 556.course_name: Foundations of Special and Inclusive Education
EDUC 556.course_description: SU, alternate years. This course explores the historical, legal, and policy foundations of special education and inclusive schooling. Emphasis is placed on special education policy and its role in shaping inclusive practices from early childhood to post-secondary education. Candidates will gain expertise in collaborative decision-making, special education referrals, eligibility determination, and the provision of services to students with disability. Coursework encourages reflection on the intersection of Christian values with educational policy. Through case study, students will evaluate existing practices and programs and formulate an advocacy-driven improvement plan for inclusive education.

EDUC 557.course_description: FA, alternate years. This course will prepare educators with the knowledge, skills and dispositions necessary to build and sustain inclusive school culture. Course content and assignments emphasize ways to develop inclusive and culturally responsive programs and practices that support social inclusion and belonging. Educators will explore inclusive educational frameworks along with current social, emotional and behavioral interventions. An ongoing inquiry project will allow educators to analyze and evaluate programs and practices shaping social inclusion and belonging in an educational setting. The inquiry project will culminate in the development of an action plan to promote inclusive culture.

EDUC 559.course_description: SP. Taking an interdisciplinary perspective, students will consider the question, “What contributes to flourishing in learning communities?,” particularly when faced with a contemporary challenge. Pulling from experiences in their full-time internship in a P-12 classroom, previous program coursework, research, and personal inquiries, students will select a challenge that transpires in their assigned placement. They will consider how self, context and the core aspects of teaching (pedagogy, curriculum, assessment, and classroom management) along with a Reformed Christian worldview inform their response and engage practice in ways that foster greater flourishing for all. Students will also complete a project tailored to their disciplinary pedagogy interests.  Prerequisite(s):

EDUC 590.course_description: FA, SP, SU, as needed. Independent study of topics of interest to particular students under supervision of a member of the department staff. The requirements for credit are determined by the supervising faculty member in collaboration with the student. Open to qualified students with permission of the Master of Education program director.

EDUC 593.course_description: FA, SP. The graduate seminar and internship is designed to integrate the components of the Educational Leadership MEd concentration. The internship allows prospective school leaders to work closely with a mentor in a school setting over a period of 10 weeks during the school year. The seminar will focus on integrating the broad unifying themes of the concentration and the internship experiences. Students will reflect on how their education and professional experiences can be used for personal growth and to influence society. The seminar and internship will include a final educational portfolio.  Prerequisite(s): all other courses in the MEd leadership concentration and permission of the educational leadership advisor.

EDUC 596.course_description: FA, SP, SU, as needed. The purpose of this course is to provide students with the opportunity to deepen their understanding of their chosen area of study and to specialize their focus through an extended program of reading guided by an instructor. Students will negotiate with their instructor a program of 2000 pages of reading (or equivalent) in their chosen area and evidence engagement with this literature through written and oral reports.

EDUC 620.course_description: FA, SP, SU. This course will examine how Christian commitments can inform pedagogical designs and processes, and not merely course content or teacher identity. Students will examine current frameworks for thinking about faith and pedagogy and interact with a range of examples of faith-informed pedagogical design before engaging in their own design process with explicit attention to its continuity with underlying faith commitments.

EDUC 621.course_description: FA, SP, SU​​​​​​​​, as needed. This course will examine how Christian thinking about interdependent community can inform pedagogical designs and processes with a focus on the relational fabric constructed during learning and in the practices of schools. Students will examine biblical, confessional, theological, and educational sources on the nature of community and explore connections to educational practices before engaging in their own design process with explicit attention to its enactment of relational patterns.

ENTR 201.course_description: FA, SP. An introduction to entrepreneurship in its various forms (e.g., scalable startups, social ventures, small businesses) and the entrepreneurial mindset required for venture success. The course emphasizes an integrated Christian view of entrepreneurship and the role of entrepreneurship in culture creation and societal impact. Students will apply business model frameworks and undertake basic research methods.

ENTR 202.course_description: FA, SP. Design Thinking is about learning processes and techniques to generate valuable insights into the needs of users, the environment and society as a whole and to use those insights to develop ideas and a variety of ways to better meet those needs through innovative products, services and programs that seek to make things better. Research techniques such as observation, interviewing and immersive empathy along with methods to prototype, test and quickly iterate ideas will be covered. The ethics of the design research techniques and the human-centered design approaches will also be explored.

ENTR 210.course_description: FA. Students who have a business or an idea for a business pursue their venture under the guidance of a mentor learning the essentials of developing and validating their business idea. As part of the process, students will analyze and reflect on how an intentionally Christian approach to entrepreneurship can shape their business. Students will gain insights into their personality and develop project management skills to strengthen their entrepreneurial effectiveness.  Prerequisite(s): permission of the instructor.

ENTR 211.course_description: SP. Students who have a business pursue their venture under the guidance of a mentor learning the essentials of growing their business. As part of the process, students will analyze and reflect on how an intentionally Christian approach to entrepreneurship can shape their business. Students develop strategies to create healthy work environments and effective marketing campaign.  Prerequisite(s):

ENTR 301.course_description: SP. Social entrepreneurship is about bringing constructive changes to social and environmental problem areas. Social entrepreneurs develop social enterprises, organizations that marshal resources and people to make changes that set the world on a more positive course. These can be either for-profit or not-for-profit organizations, but their primary missions are to address social or environmental needs in powerful and sustainable ways. Students will build on ideas and tools learned in

ENTR 302.course_description: SP. This course provides hands-on learning on how to launch a startup through the rapid development and testing of ideas by gathering customer and marketplace feedback. Startups face uncertainty and high levels of risk. Students learn how to reduce both uncertainty and risk by engaging actual customers in search of the jobs they do, their pain points, and their unmet needs. Only by doing so can the entrepreneur develop a proper solution and establish a suitable business model that is scalable. This class utilizes a lean startup approach that provides the steps needed to build a successful startup.  Prerequisite(s):

ENTR 303.course_description: SP. An integrated study of the business management principles applicable to the challenges and opportunities unique to small businesses. Emphasizes strategic analysis of management, marketing, and financial issues facing small firms primarily from an entrepreneurial perspective. Includes lectures, case studies, and the development of a comprehensive business plan.  Prerequisite(s):

ENTR 304.course_description: SP. Students learn how to obtain, deploy and return capital over the financing life cycle of entrepreneurial ventures in a way that aligns with their faith. Students learn how to prepare and explain basic financial statements, analyze and predict cash flows, and value an entrepreneurial venture. Learning methods includes readings, lectures, financial analysis, and case studies.  Prerequisite(s):

ENTR 383.course_description: FA, SP, SU. Students work at least 60 hours in a position that must be related to their major. May be repeated multiple times for credit. No more than 12 credit hours of internship and/or practicum can be counted toward graduation requirements. International students enrolled in this course may apply for CPT authorization. Online.  Prerequisite(s): ot open to first-year students. Must be a major in department and have received approval from the department. Applications are initiated through the Career Center. Students find their own position, which must be approved by the Career Center and the department.

ENTR 391.course_description: SP. This course introduces students to a sociological perspective on everyday social settings by applying methods of systematic, qualitative observation. Training includes ethnographic research methodologies designed to equip students to collect and analyze data. Topics include issues of access, rapport, participant observation, field notes, ethics, interviewing, coding, and analysis. Crosslisted as

IDIS 301.course_name: Introduction to TESOL and Bilingual Education
IDIS 301.course_description: FA, alternate years. This course focuses on methods, pedagogies, and strategies for TESOL and bilingual education, including linguistic, cognitive, affective, and social factors that influence the acquisition of a second language. Additional topics include policies, program models, culture, teaching in content areas, curricular design, and special populations. Students will identify ways in which Christian faith relates to understanding the role and value of languages and multilingualism and the impact of that understanding in an educational setting. Field experience required.

IDIS 311.course_name: Assessment for TESOL and Bilingual Education
IDIS 311.course_description: SP, alternate years. This course focuses on the design, implementation, and analysis of assessment measures for English learners and students in bilingual education. Students will understand various types of assessments and how features of assessment measures and evaluative tools used for English learners can foster justice or injustice. In addition, the course will address questions about assessing language difficulties versus learning disabilities.  Prerequisite(s):

IDIS 356.course_description: FA, alternate years. Theory and practice of teaching world languages in the elementary school. Study of methodologies, curricula, and programs. Off-campus field experience and observations required. Education students take this course in the junior or senior year, prior to the student teaching internship.

IDIS 357.course_description: FA, alternate years. An introduction to the major principles and practices of teaching world languages, offering a study of various methodologies and the major controversies associated with them. The course explores how a Christian approach to education affects second-language pedagogy and how this pedagogy interacts with the language learner’s personal growth. It also introduces the prospective educator to the teaching of the basic skills, to issues in evaluation and assessment, and to the use of technologies in the language classroom. Education students take this course in the junior or senior year, prior to the student teaching internship.

IDIS 358.course_description: SP, alternate years. A field experience in TESOL or bilingual education at the elementary, middle, secondary or adult level depending on the candidate’s program. In addition to the field experience, interns meet weekly on campus with the university supervisor to discuss and reflect upon approaches and challenges encountered in the field experience placement. Students demonstrate various teaching methods in the TESOL or bilingual education setting.  Prerequisite(s):

IDIS 375.course_name: Methods and Pedagogies for Secondary Social Studies
IDIS 375.course_description: FA This seminar applies an active, student-centered learning approach in order to introduce students to the methods and practices of teaching the humanities and social sciences, including economics, geography, government, history, and psychology at the middle and high school level. The course prepares students for student teaching by providing practical instruction in curricular standards, unit planning, lesson planning, teaching resources, classroom methods, and assessment instruments, and exploring these in light of Christian understandings of human nature and pedagogy. This course should normally be taken before student teaching.  Prerequisite(s): Internship I (

ENST 210.course_description: FA, SP. As population and affluence have increased and technology’s role has grown, human activities have transformed natural environments around the globe. This course begins with key elements and processes in biophysical systems and examines how a wide variety of human enterprises such as agriculture, industry, recreation, and urbanization have altered and continue to alter those systems. The impacts are assessed by standards such as ecological well-being and sustainability, human habitability, and quality of life.

ENST 285.course_description: FA. This course examines the job market and graduate programs in environmental sciences. Topics include exploring environmental careers as part of a broader Christian vocation as well as career options and necessary qualifications. Students conduct personal evaluations, prepare a resume, and set career goals. This course also pairs students with environmental programs/organizations, primarily at Calvin University, where they apply the concepts, principles, and skills they are learning as part of the environmental science or environmental studies major (e.g., the Ecosystem Preserve, Plaster Creek Stewards, or Coastal Cleanup). The course is pass/fail and is intended for students in their second year.

ENST 301.course_description: FA. This course traces the development of American environmentalism in the late 19th and 20th centuries. It begins with dramatic transformation of the American landscape in the 19th century. After tracing early efforts to protect forests and scenery in the Progressive Era, the course explores the environmental movement in the post-war era and development of modern environmental law. While focusing on the dominant environmental movement, the course highlights marginalized environmental movements, such as the environmental justice movement. The course ends with a critical discussion of the contemporary sustainability movement.  Prerequisite(s):

ENST 302.course_description: FA. This course introduces the field of environmental law from its constitutional foundations to recent judicial decisions. The course focuses on questions of legal authority in the American federalist system and on the most significant legal processes that students will likely encounter in environmental careers.  Prerequisite(s):

SPAN 300.course_description: FA. In this course, dual-enrolled Spanish immersion students learn about pan-Latino identity and globalization and develop the skills needed to succeed in college-level studies, with an emphasis on the development of their academic writing skills. This course gives special attention given to the effects of globalization on Spanish speakers from Central and South America and Spain. A minimum grade of C (2.0) in this course is required as a prerequisite to continue in the Spanish Immersion program.  Prerequisite(s): Students must be a junior or senior high school student in an approved Spanish immersion program. Students must also have achieved a score of 4 or better on the AP Spanish Language and Culture exam. Exceptions may be evaluated on a case-by-case basis by Spanish faculty. Corequisite(s): enrollment in an approved high-school Spanish immersion program.

SPAN 305.course_name: Engaging Hispanic Culture in Place for Immersion Students
SPAN 305.course_description: SU, as needed. In this four-week intensive course, which is taught onsite by a Calvin professor at one of the locations of our collaborating host institutions (currently Tegucigalpa, Honduras; Mérida, Mexico; Arequipa, Peru; Oviedo, Spain), Spanish Immersion students are immersed in the life and culture of a specific Spanish-speaking country. Students live with host families and attend lectures and discussion classes focusing on aspects of local culture and history. Particular attention will be given to how history and culture inform important social systems such as the economy, political structures, education and health. Students also participate in excursions to important historical and cultural sites and attend religious and cultural events.  Prerequisite(s):

SPAN 306.course_description: SU, as needed. In this four-week intensive course, which is taught onsite by a Calvin professor at one of the locations of our collaborating host institutions (currently Tegucigalpa, Honduras; Mérida, Mexico; Arequipa, Peru; Oviedo, Spain), undergraduate students are immersed in the life and culture of a specific Spanish-speaking country. Students live with host families and attend lectures and discussion classes focusing on aspects of local culture and history. Particular attention will be given to how history and culture inform important social systems such as the economy, political structures, education and health. Students also participate in excursions to important historical and cultural sites and attend religious and cultural events.  Prerequisite(s):

SPAN 308.course_name: Introduction to the Hispanic World I
SPAN 308.course_description: FA. This course introduces students to major developments of the Hispanic World from antiquity through the Enlightenment. Discussions center on the relationship of major literary and artistic works to economic, political, religious, and social developments in the Iberian Peninsula and the Castilian colonies in the Americas. This course, normally the first in a sequence of two, prepares students for advanced-topics courses. An oral presentation and a research paper are required.  Prerequisite(s):

SPAN 309.course_name: Introduction to the Hispanic World II
SPAN 309.course_description: SP. This course introduces students to major developments of the Hispanic World from the independence of the Spanish American colonies to the present day. Discussions center on the relationship of major literary and artistic works to economic, political, religious, and social developments in Spain and Spanish America. In addition, students develop their skills in reading and evaluating literature in a second language through representative texts, and they sharpen their skills in critical writing and analysis.
